products.name: Kleenex Ultra Soft Facial Tissues, Medium Count Flat, 170 ct, 6 Pack. Designs May Vary

detail.comments: We are a family of allergy sufferers, so we know our tissues. Kleenex Super Soft are comforting to the nose, without added lotion to smear up our eyeglass lenses when we clean them. Also, I can't put my finger on why, but each tissue seems to last significantly longer than a typical tissue.
I use more Kleenex products than anyone else!! Love them.

These tissues aren't going to sparkle and take you away to a magical land. But hey, what did you expect? They're tissues.
Realistically, these tissues do what they'e supposed to... they catch your snot, which is gross. They aren't the softest tissues I've ever used, but they aren't the most rough either. The boxes are nearly twice the size of your standard tissue box (or at least they look like it). Apparently the size of the box is both a plus and con. If you like more tissues or doing crafts with large, leftover boxes (way to go re-users), then a big box is for you. If you don't like reaching your hand into a large tissue box, then you probably won't like this. Frankly, these are the largest tissue boxes I've ever seen.
After having owned this little collection of giant tissue boxes for some time now, I can tell you the real incentive to buy these tissues is that you will get a LOT of them. I sneeze almost every day since it's Spring and I can't see a time in the near future when I run out of tissues. Maybe it says somewhere in the description exactly how many tissues you're getting, but I think they could easily make a commercial for these using a "how many tissues does it take to get to the bottom of our tissue boxes" commercial slogan. If someone tries this, let me know because now I'm curious.
AS EXPECTED
They are Kleenex, of course they are great.
Great product, still using them, thanks.

Great! Thanks

products.name: Google Wifi system (set of 3) - Router replacement for whole home coverage

detail.comments:
I have a home office upstairs with the router downstairs and had been using an extender, but the speed was ~1/5 what it should be and would periodically drop for a second.
The Google WiFi was simple to install with the phone app and I have fairly consistent speed throughout the house now.

Had my first one for about two weeks before I returned it. My wired connection was constantly being dropped. Sent it back hoping that it was just that unit. Well my new one does the same thing. If you rely on a hard wired connection then avoid this unit. The wireless is great, but for some reason it constantly drops connection on my wired network.

Simply the best router I have ever owned. Setup is extremely simple and up running in 10 min. No DDNS support but that you don't know what it is then you don't need it. It has only one port on each unit but multiple port switch is cheap.

I live in a 5500 sqf home and this product solved all my wireless issues. I had purchased 6 of these and now I'm able to receive good coverage throughout the entire house. My lan top speed is around 100-120 mbs average, this mesh system is distributing the wifi signal around 109 mbs in most areas of the house and around 20-80 mbs in areas that I never had wifi signal before.

I was using the equipment U-verse provided and could not get a strong enough wifi signal to much of anything. The setup was super easy and the functionality and options are enough to manage the network to your liking. I achieve speeds similar to a wired connection...truly amazing!!

Works like a charm and is very easy to set up. While it's not technically a signal booster, in effect it does the same thing, creating a stronger and better network throughout your house. I was skeptical about the skimpy setup instructions included, but all you have to do is to plug the first unit into your modem with the supplied ethernet cable, plug it in, download the Google Wi-Fi app and the app will walk you through the entire remaining setup process. Couldn't be easier. If you're a Comcast customer with a dual band modem/router, the Google system will work without disabling the Comcast router and both systems will work in parallel. You can, however, disable the Comcast router if you desire.

This thing is phenomenal! I used to have a 25 Mbps Comcast service at home, then moved temporarily to an apartment complex. I could barely achieve 8-9 Mbps on a good day, and it would often drop to 0.xx. I asked them for a faster Internet and got a 75 Mbps plan. Once again, it averaged 8-9 Mbps on a good day. No change whatsoever, compared to the 25 Mbps plan. Then I bought Google. The moment I set it up (easy) and measured the speed: boooom > constant 89 Mbps!!! Ten times more than the previous average. And even more than the 75 Mbps plan. HIghly recommended.
This solved our internet problems and we had tried extenders, new modems, etc.
All I can say is this product is amazing. Took me about 5 minutes to set up. Buy buy buy!
they are expensive but they work well

I used 2 sets of these to create a mesh network for a church with 4 buildings. I get consistent wifi speed anywhere on campus. The access point that is farthest from my main point is getting about 4mb/s less than what we subscribe to Centurylink for. Overall, I am pleased with the ease of use via the app and performance of these little guys.

Wifi system is good. Concept is good. But product is half baked. You don't get speeds above 40mbps on the satellites. Coverage per satellite is very less in an concrete house. Does not cover more than 1200sq feet in a concrete structure.

I live in New Jersey and enjoyed playing casino games from Atlantic City at home. You have to be physically located in NJ to do this and whatever geo-locator feature is employed by this device will not recognize that I am located in NJ. I went through two levels of supervisors at Google support and they agree that it is their device preventing me from playing. I picked up the free router available through my ISP and it works fine. If you live in NJ and like to "place your bets" steer clear!
Great product. Fast ship

I cant believe a company like google is producing such an crap.
I really had so much hope for it. I cant believe it.
To make it short:
Pro:
- Nice coverage
- Good Speed
- Easy to "not" configure (bc you literally cant configure anything) :)
Negative:
1.) If you can connect your router into google wifi your wont have much problems, but google will get all your traffic (if you dont care, this is perfect for you).
2.) I want to use it behind a router, this is not possible, atleast not with the mesh feature, also it doesnt support hardwired mesh. Currently i set up 2 of the 3 in bridge mode, it works, nice coverage and best speed i ever saw.
But it lacks literally EVERYTHING you need if you want some advanced network stuff like port forwarding. If you dont route all your traffic over gwifi, you cant reach WLAN -> LAN or LAN -> WLAN (so you cant connect to your e.g. babycameras via mobile) or cant reach your wlan printer (srsly!).
I think they will patch this all eventually, now some will come and say: you suck blabla I just say: I currently use 2 different routers from 2 different ISPs and then i add another router which does the Load Balancing -> it all works flawlessly (!) I have 3 different subnets and they all can reach each other. So its technially possible, but google doesnt seem to care.
Lets see if they fix this, than its the best wlan in the world..

I don't usually leave reviews but this system merits one. Very impressed. Our house is deep (about 300 feet front to back) and the cable is in the front. I have struggled through three different wi-fi routers and multiple repeaters over the past few years trying to get even coverage to no avail. Enter the Google Wifi system (Set of 3) which did the trick immediately. 175 Mbps near the hub and 110 Mbps at the back of the house in the middle of the day (our internet package claims speeds up to 250 Mbps however, unless you are on at 2 am, 170 to 190 is about the best you are going to get). 10 minutes to set up. No fuss and no problems so far. Will update if anything comes up.
Bottom line: If you are looking for wi-fi that simply works I highly recommend this mesh system.

We have a pretty big house, not just in square footage but in the unusual way it is laid out. Before I had two routers with different SSIDs which was a pain and never worked great. Once I got the Google Wifi set up it was fantastic. The one thing to be sure of is that everything in your network is downstream of the device that is acting as the router, i.e. the one attached to your cable/dsl. Once I figured this out things could not be better. Devices switch from one to the other seamlessly so I basically always have maximum strength. I have wired internet so I am able to use that for the backhaul so I don't know how it would be without that, but withit things are very fast.
Finally, home wifi that is secure and fast. Very easy to setup and maintain.
Amazing. Range was even better than expected.
The speed has slowed down a bit. However the wifi cover is excellent.

Bought one officially from Google Store and setup was a breeze, the GUI for management is very sleek and everything you need is at least 3 taps away. I bought this one for my dorm as the provided wireless network could only push out 40Mbps on a good day and other times would just flat out refuse to work so I decided to purchase this and use the provided wired Ethernet connection to use as the uplink.
Included is a speedtest screenshot and a picture of the device sitting on the desk. The brightness is turned all the way up and very pretty to look at. Even after 24 hours of operation it only is slightly warm on the bottom half of the device but not burning hot. Data transfers from devices connected to the device was incredible with an unprecedented 38MB/s (304 Mbps) from a wireless client to a device attached to the LAN gigabit port on the device.
For everything this device has done right it isn't however without some flaws. The first thing I noticed was there was no way for you to set your own local LAN IP address subnet and it's locked at 192.168.86.x which granted for a small home network or even for someone who isn't into digging into the nitty gritty with their network it isn't that big of an issue but for me I'm hoping we get the feature in the coming updates. The second issue is the lack of a web interface for which to manage the device from. I understand that in this day and age if you don't have some sort of smartphone device you're most likely living under a rock but having the ability to do so really helps in decreasing the heavy dependence on such devices. I didn't remove a star because even though those features are missing it hasn't affected my utilization and use of the device.
The fact that the devices are protected with TPS and will only run Google-signed software its at least a peace of mind that nobody is going to hijack your devices in the middle of the night and is the first devices I have used to actually have that feature. The dual broadcast SSID on both the 2.4 and 5 GHz bands is a blessing since you don't have to worry about which wireless network you're connected to at a given time and it will automatically switch to whichever one your device supports and is in optimal range to utilize.
Ultimately though until they allow you to specify your LAN network I would not recommend this where you need more than a /24 (253 usable addresses) on your wireless network. For everything else, absolutely.

Setup was simple, equipment design is beautiful and it worked BUT area coverage was no better than my original single-router configuration and speed was about HALF the previous set-up. It's a cute idea, but the mesh network doesn't improve anything.
I've been using this for the last week and it works well. Set up was a snap.
Awesome! Installed it in less then 3 Min.

I'm not an expert on the "Mesh" technology that drives these, but I have a set of 3 that does my entire 3-story house and far out into the backyard (we have about .25 acre). Easy to set up. Just download the app and follow the directions.

A little nervous about coverage. My home is 2760 square feet over 2 stories. Basically 1400 square feet on each floor. This wifi system has excellent coverage throughout my home. So, unless you have a sprawling single story home, one router should be sufficient if it's located somewhere in the middle of your home. BTW, I love the fact I can turn off individual users. Especially since I have 3 kids in the home.
Easy Setup

Set up was extremely easy. I have an older smart TV and when I upgraded my wireless router a couple of years ago my TV would not recognize it so my TV was no longer smart. With this mesh system I placed one of the units near my TV and connected them using an ethernet cable. Now my smart TV is smart again.
The only criticism that I have is about the ethernet cable that is included to connect one unit to the modem. There is no writing on the cable so I am not sure what CAT type it is supposed to be. I have gigabit internet and when I did my first speed test my download speed was only 350MBS. Thought perhaps that I had just spent a lot of money on a mesh system that was not going to meet my needs. Then I replaced the cable that Google provided with a CAT6 cable and my download speed was 940MBS. Either the included cable is junk or mine was defective.
Good but hard to find the best point to place your Gwifi. Overall speed are amazing and no interrupted connection.

This product is awful I came to expect more from google. The huge issue is the inability to use both bridge mode and mesh networks. That is a very basic needed option. They also do not work in mixed wired/wireless modes. The three pack would be ideal as 2 for inside a modest house with a third covering an outbuilding but again mesh doesn't work when more than one device is wired. This means all devices can only talk to each other wireless. This means it will not work if signal doesn't travel well through your upstairs/downstairs which is the point of buying devices like these.
I would recommend ubnt's unifi for power users and AmpliFi for anyone that wants a simple to use product.

Compact, easy to setup, responsive, and inexpensive. Great choice to upgrade a nonsmart tv or an older model smart tv for faster button response.

This is my first experience with Roku. Excellent streaming with NO interruptions. I went from using a Sony Blue Ray player which was the best at the time, but it often stopped streaming right in the middle of a show or movie I was watching. A friend of mine who works in the A/V and custom home theater business recommended I switch to Roku. He was right...fast streaming with no interruptions. I've only been using it for a couple of weeks so I haven't explored the other options and channels available yet. I understand it's great with Amazon Prime video, too, and I guess I'll sign up for that soon.

I'm considering subscribing to some streaming services, and I don't have much money to spend on entertainment, so the Roku Stick 3600R seemed like the way to go. It plugs into your television's HDMI port, pairs with its remote, you register on Roku's web site, and you are good to go. You can install whatever channels you like from Roku's selection, sign into those that require a subscription, or just watch free channels. Set-up is simple. I recommend watching the instructional video on Roku's web site. The only hitch I encountered was that the remote would not pair with the Roku at first. In this case, unplug the Roku from its power source, take the batteries out of the remote, plug the Roku back in, and reinstall the batteries, in that order. Then it will pair.
The Roku Stick is 3 1/4"L x 3/4"W x 3/8"D. It sticks out 2 7/8" when plugged into an HDMI port. If your television does not allow that much space, Roku will send you a free 4-inch flexible extender, which you can request on their web site. You will need the serial number to request an extender. Roku ships them out quickly. When you buy the Stick, a remote control and a power cord that can be plugged into a USB port or into a AC outlet are included. Roku recommends plugging the Stick into an AC outlet, if possible, for a more consistent power source. The remote requires two AAA batteries, also included. You can also control the Roku using their free app for iOS or Android. My internet connection offers only 5-6 Mbps download speed, but this is sufficient for streaming.
I don't have any paid subscription channels, so I'll comment on the free offerings. For free movies and old TV shows, the choices are Crackle, Popcornflix, FilmRise, and Tubitv. Most selections are in the B-movie category, but there are some gems. The biggest frustration is the lack of ability to search across multiple free channels, if I'm looking for something particular. You can search across the major pay channels. If you want news channels, they are there, but most content is prerecorded. If you can't get international news like Al Jazeera English, RT, France 24 over the air, watching them on Roku is an option, but, again, they are prerecorded clips. There is some nice specialty content, like Poker Central, but most free channels consist of relatively short pre-recorded material.
The single technical problem I have with the Roku is that it interferes with my television's over-air antenna. I see this problem mentioned from time to time on the Roku forum. It is probably due to the antenna cable being insufficiently shielded. Mine is not shielded at all, in fact. But I cannot get the local CBS affiliate with the Roku plugged in, and I have sporadic problems with multiple PBS stations in my area. The only solution is to unplug the Roku Stick from both the power source and the television. This is a nuisance. Some people who use antennae are affected, while some are not. It seems to depend, not only on the cable's shielding, but on proximity to a station's broadcast tower and probably the position of the Roku relative to the antenna.
By the way, the Roku Streaming Stick 3600R and 3600RW are the same device. The 3600RW is a product offered by Walmart that is co-branded with Vudu. It has a Vudu button on the remote instead of a Google Play button, and it comes with a $5 Vudu coupon. That is the only difference. I like my Roku Stick, but its value is going to depend on whether you need it to stream channels you are paying for or, if not, how much value you find in the free channels and whether or not it interferes with your antenna, if you don't have cable. Assuming the Roku Stick lasts a few years, I think it will be a reasonable value just for the free channels. But that's not a given, which may be surprising, considering the number of channels available.

products.name: NETGEAR Nighthawk AC1750 Smart Dual Band WiFi Router (R6700)

detail.comments: Great wireless router. I have Xfininity for internet and their equipment has average at best. This greatly improved my internet speed and streaming. Also has good range to my outdoor area!

Was never able to get to the admin page for this router. Even after factory reset, could not access the admin page by wireless or by either net cable. Will return to Netgear as I am past the 30 day amazon return window.

The Netgear AC2300 Nighthawk is one of the best medium to high end consumer routers out there. It is easy to set up while at the same time offering plenty of advanced features for more technically-included folks, including the ability to install DD-WRT if you really want to geek out. For less technically inclined folks, setup is easy, with a wizard walking you though all the basic configuration options, including the all important configuration of the wireless networks.
Performance is excellent; the Wi-Fi easily covered the entire main floor of our home and handled all the wireless devices we threw at it. This isn't magic; normal sources of interference will still cause issues, but for modern devices that can take advantage of the multiple antennas you will likely see a speed increase. I set up the 2.4 ghz radio to be legacy, for older devices, and set the 5 ghz to be the latest and greatest for my newer devices, and this seems to have worked well.
There's not too many downsides to the router; I wish it has more Ethernet ports, but all routers in this class seem to stick with four so not a big deal. The design also takes up a bit of space, but given the performance this isn't a big deal.
All in all, a great mid to high end router at a competitive price.
Works better than expected with my fiber optics 1 gig internet.

This thing stopped working 3-4 months after purchase. My AT&T Gigapower Router/Modem outperformed this "supposedly" beast.
I stream/game so my business relies heavily on the internet. Tried to contact NETGEAR and they did not do anything to help nor spec the possibility that it's a defect. I am very dissatisfied by their product and support. Gigapower 1Gb Up and 1Gb Down, I was getting 100Mb up/down...

What is worth mentioning is that if you spend more you'll get something better and that's usually the case. I didn't see the need of going to a more expensive router than this because the ability to link more devices than what this one is capable of is not a feature I need. We have tablets and phones and a laptop connected wireless, other devices are wired. The Netgear Nighthawk covers both levels of our house (3400sq.ft. combined) and gives a usable signal outdoors for about a hundred feet around the house. We don't have any metal siding or foil coated sheathing on the house which would obstruct the signal. It's installed above ground level, not in the basement. You can download a manual from the Netgear web site that will describe the feature set.
Extremely fast and very easy to configure.

Installation was super easy. Basically it was plug and play. The speed is WAY faster than the Nighthawk 6200 that I replaced with this model. The signal to the various devices in the house get dropped way less.

their tech support is a big scam.wasted 1hr40min and they wanted to sell me a policy.had a friend that worked years for I B M get it to work.

It took a while to set up (30 minutes), but I was documenting all the setups as I went.
I replaced my 10 year old Netgear router with the Nighthawk.
The router works great for me and I'm happy to have the newest security protocols.
Very fast and reliable. Have used this router for a few weeks now and streaming is flawless. Also have used with online gaming. Very good product and would definitely recommend.
Great quality router
Satisfactory

I have had this router for a month now. So far it has worked beautifully. Super easy to install and have yet to have a problem with it. I needed a new router that could handle our amount of devices. We run 3 smart phones, tivo box, 2 tablets, laptop, xbox one, ps4, roku, and fire stick. More often than not, almost all devices are running at the same time. We were constantly restarting our old router because wifi connections kept dropping. My cousin recommended this router to me, and I'm very happy I listened to him.

BEWARE! The amazon reviews are showing up for ALL models within the Nighthawk product line. The model I purchased was the AC2350. Amazon should not be listing my review (or the review of others) for the other models. My review has no bearing on the AC3200, for example. Given this, it's hard not to recommend simply staying away from the entire product line as you have no real way to determine the lemons from the possible good devices.
A search on google for this router's model and "dropping wi-fi" will lead you to results that clearly illustrate that this device has a serious problem with randomly dropping your wi-fi signal. My laptop maintains my wi-fi at work where we have a cheap < $50 access point. I got this router for my home in hopes that it would be faster and more stable than my previous router. Sadly, after about 2 months I started to notice that this thing will drop your wi-fi at least once an hour if not more frequently than that. I have since had to connect via an Ethernet cable when I am working at my desk, but this doesn't help when trying to stream video to the TV. In any case, I doubt I will be giving Netgear another chance. Do yourself a favor and buy a different brand.
It stopped working :-( Restarted the router and modem too and ever since the connection is flaky. Tried all sorts things but still the same.

I BOUGHT THIS TO REPLACE THE ROUTER SUPPLIED BY MY CABLE COMPANY. ITS LOCATED IN THE LOWER LEVEL OF MY HOUSE & STILL GIVES A GREAT SIGNAL THROUGHOUT THE ENTIRE HOUSE. WAY BETTER THAN THE ONE I HAD. DEFINETLY RECOMMEND.

So far this is working great.I can get some really good distance to. I was about 100 yds from it and was still able to use the Wifi. Only problem with this distance is Wifi thieves, and I was having that problem. But I stopped him form doing it anymore, with this router you can go to the website and block all new devices from connecting to the wifi. Very Nice. Since I blocked all new devices I haven't had any problems with those low-life wifi thieves.
Works great! Significantly improved not just the speed of my internet... but also the quality!
Very happy with purchase, the router has worked great and everyone in house loves the access we get.
Awesome. I couldn't get a decent signal in my bedroom due to the concrete walls. I love it.

Worked fantastic for a month - great speed, zero problems. Just a bit after a month, I started getting WiFi drops. Several devices, both on 2.4 as well as 5 frequencies, would show the SSIDs as available, but there would be no internet connection. I have tried changing the settings according to Netgear articles. I updated the firmware to the latest. I used WiFi analyzer to find the least used channels in my vicinity. The router is still periodically dropping WiFi, which makes tasks like gaming very aggravating. The wired Ethernet connections have always been perfect. In fact, I was streaming movies on the TV via a wired Roku, and while the WiFi dropped, the streams kept going 100%. So, I know the issue is not with my ISP or cable modem.
Netgear's customer service scheduled a phone appointment with me, and didn't call me. Then tried rescheduling the call the next day. This was frustrating as well. Thought they would just give me a number to call right away.

products.name: Ubiquiti Networks Unifi 802.11ac Dual-Radio PRO Access Point (UAP-AC-PRO-US)

detail.comments: Great product. Speed is faster than previous models and price is lower.
Amazing product. Coverage is great no slowness at all. I would recommend to family. The preformanfe is solid and consistent. I like the look too.

Ok, I have been a Network Engineer for 25 years. At work it is all things Cisco. At home... Ubiquiti. For the cost, they are the best. Granted, I still front end the SG with an ASA (old habits die hard). Their controller software is top notch. Picture all the things that HP and CA tried to sell you for a management platform... and now picture it ACTUALLY working without the 1M budget. Aside from my home DMZ, everything behind that is Ubiquiti... core, distro, access, and ap's. The SAN is from someone else, but, if they built one, I would look at it.
Thanks guys.

I thought this was the greatest thing to enter my home, but then suddenly I go from 250mbps down to 93mbps for no apparent reason. I'm not a dummy, I know what I'm doing and I know how to configure a network, I know it's nothing I did. However, I did update the firmware so I'm sure that has something to do with it. If they do not fix this issue soon I'll be asking for a refund from Amazon. I will change my review when this is resolved.

Wow - what a disappointment!
Turns out that this device REQUIRES the use of the Unifi Controller software for setup, configuration and future changes. Unlike nearly every other AP, router etc, it CANNOT be accessed directly through a GUI. To make matters worse, the Controller would not start for us on Win 7. The locator software found the device, but it could never be accessed.
After Googling this problem and seeing how many people were dealing with the same issue -- with causes ranging from: conflicting ports, to wrong Java script versions, to default install directory problems (software doesn't even allow you decide the install path, then puts itself in a Linux/Unix-like dir structure that appears to create problems for Windows), and more -- I have decided to return the unit. Setting up an AP should never be this complicated.

Works! what else can you hope for? in any case for home this is great, i would expect this to work for business just as well. Did single unit install replacing my old AP which was starting to show some issues.
Software is something to get used to, just download it from their website. Config is quick once you figure out what to press and where. I could not connect to AP directly through the browser, but that is not an issue once you have the software installed.
I recommend this if you are looking for a new AP.
will not buy retail router ever again
Perfect. Thanks so much!

I recently bought this and have only had it for a few days (time of writing obviously) but so far it has been a real eye opener. This is from someone that normally would buy your typical mid-high end wireless home routers from ASUS, ASROCK, TP-LINK etc..
Now, I am no Network Engineer and/or IT Specialist but I am what can be considered a "prosumer" or "power-user". I know plenty of advanced topics and concepts in networking but in no way to the deep level understanding that a professional Network or IT engineer would. That said, I've only had it a few days and being a relatively simple product (in terms of what its main purpose is) I will go over the main differences "I" noticed when moving to an AP + Gateway/Router + Modem HOME solution instead of the typically Wireless Router + Modem only solution.
The first thing you will immediately notice is that this is NOT going to be plug n play like a wireless router would. Now, that is not to say that this is a pain to setup but just FYI this will require at least a bit of effort besides hooking up Ethernet cable(s) and applying power. Now, as a prosumer I like tinkering and what not so this is fine by me. Honestly, the most time-consuming part of this process is mounting it. Actually setting it up software wise is extremely easy. The inevitable question will come up...do I have to mount it on the ceiling/wall? NO you do not. It can be just sitting somewhere on a flat surface if you wish but obviously its not recommended not because it won't work but because wireless coverage/throughput won't be at its best and if your spending this much to upgrade your home wireless network you might as well go the extra mile and get everything you can out of it.
The software you literally just follow the instructions, download the controller software to a PC/Laptop/HomeServer ect... and execute. The software is intuitive and you will pick up on the GUI quickly with simple exploration/discovery. It handles the initialization, configuration & monitoring of the AP.
Now for the impressions. MASSIVE difference compared to having a singular Wireless Router powering your whole house/apartment. In my case, I have about an ~1200 sqft apartment. I mounted it on the ceiling near the center of the apartment in the most open area (Living Room + Dining Room + Kitchen) and used a 50ft CAT5e shielded UTP Ethernet cable to neatly route it back to my now WIRED only router (If you are staying with a wireless router, disable ALL radios) + POE Switch Combo. My whole apartment is literally covered with "Full Bars" of coverage. The lowest point I could find was way back in the Master Bedroom where it was a good -62 dBm (Anything above -65 dBm is good IMO). Before, I could not go to my Bedroom without experiencing intermittent drops and/or LAG. Not to mention that when I did have a connection there it was sometimes slow, as in Youtube constantly buffering slow. This is no longer the case and I am really impressed. The Controller software also has some pretty advanced features which I like and the interface and how it shows you stats and data is really neat and slick. The LED Blue light CAN be turned off if you wish.
Overall, really satisfied and will no longer rely on wireless routers or all-in-one solutions again. Honestly, although it is more work, it is far worth it to avoid hassling with the router and the frustration of dealing with slow internet when you KNOW you are paying for high speed internet (In my case its 200 Down, 20 Up) and are not getting those results. Now granted, this is wireless we are talking about so you will RARELY get your full internet speed if your roaming around or not in line of sight of the AP. In my case, If I am in the living room or anywhere within line of sight and maybe 20-40 ft away It will get pretty close sometimes even full speed (Average I'd say 170-180 mbps out of 200 Max). Anywhere not line of sight and an appreciable distance away will drop it to an average of 90-120 mbps which is STILL EXCELLENT compared to my previous numbers of 5-10!! This is on both the 2.4 GHZ and 5 GHZ bands as well as using an AC device (Galaxy S Phone).
If your case is similar to mine and don't mind tinkering, DITCH the wireless router and get a good Wired Router/Gateway because those have much better hardware for handling plenty of traffic since they don't worry about radios. BUY this AP because of its easy and slick GUI AND the fact that the company Ubiquiti has other products that have similar design style and will integrate nicely together with ONE software package (Big deal for me maybe not for others). Highly Recommended!
Thesea re amazing for the price point. Not for home or amateur users, a bit involved to configure, then rock solid

I've installed several of these in an enterprise situation and have been very pleased with the performance. It was a no-brainer when I wanted to upgrade my home access point and I've been very satisfied. Although you need to install the controller software on a PC for initial set up it does not need to run 24/7. After the access point is configured it can run standalone.

Love it! Went from high end Asus' to this. Use to require 2 Asus routers with 6 external antennas each to cover my house. One of these guys does the same thing in the same position as the main Asus was. Upgraded everything to ubiquiti. Got the edgerouter pro from a friend at a good price, and put in a 16port poe unifi switch. Everything is fast, stable, and reasonably priced.

I've worked in and taught classes in IT Networking since 1980. Over the last decade wireless technology has improved at a fast pace. My old Wireless Access Point was solid (always a good connection) but I wanted an upgrade that supported current standards. Although I was accustom to Enterprise APs that we installed at the University, because of cost I first tried a Consumer grade AP from a commonly known vender. The wireless signal would drop out often so I returned it. I then discovered and purchased Ubiquiti AP and have been very pleased. No dropping of signal and I have complete coverage in my two story home.
Pro:
- The AP supports PoE (Power over Ethernet), comes with an injector to send power to the unit. This let me install the AP in the ceiling of my second floor home
- The controller software is free to download and runs in Windows or Mac OS
- Looks and performs like an Enterprise AP (Cisco) but no licensing.
- Supports current technology
Con:
- Some learning curve may be required if not familiar with the technology terms

No matter what I tried, I couldn't get the Java controller app to work, it would just hang forever, saying "Starting UniFi Controller..." This access point is not managed through a browser on Windows 10, you have to install Java and run a special Java app (an app that didn't work). Also, not all the advertised features of the AP work unless you constantly run the app somewhere, like as a background Windows service, which you have to configure yourself on some other machine that must always be running or install some kind of "Cloud Key" (read the docs). Also, it seems that this AP often talks to the manufacturer's web site (search the Internet to see others talking about it), so, what if you block all Internet traffic to/from the AP at the perimeter, are there other features that will stop working then? Is it spying for marketing reasons? Who knows...but it's not worth the hassle, I'm returning it, and have already ordered a different AP. Kudos to Amazon for making returns easy.

Awesome WAP with tons of features and great performance. I have deployed many different business class wireless access points with a variety of customer needs and expectations. These units consistently outperform most others, especially when considering cost and features. Ubiquiti's Unifi platform is similar to Cisco's Meraki platform in which you can manage these units from the cloud. With that being said Unifi is not quite at the level of Meraki, but they sure are close! The performance you get out these is amazing considered their price. With the Unifi controller software you can manage them locally, or remotely if you decide to use their cloud key. The cloud key is a device that you plug into your switch that runs a version of the Unifi controller software. You can then link that to your Unifi cloud account for remote access. This is particularly helpful if you are not geographically close to the install location.
Once you have the Unifi controller software setup, either on a local computer, or the cloud key, you can search for and add each Unifi device to your network. There is also a google chrome extension that will scan your network to help you find them. I recommend setting each device with a static IP in order to make them easier to find later.
Overall great wireless access points! I have yet to be let down by Ubiquiti and will continue to highly recommend them.
Creates a seamless wireless network
Great AP. No reboots and very fast.

First Ubiquiti product and I'm sold! Took me a few minutes to get setup, forgot to write down the admin password I created and it tooke me about 30 minutes to realize if you do that you have to uninstall the software and delete the backup in order to start over.
No complai
Excellent all around
Great value! Setup is easy, all web-based. WiFi signal works well.

I'm really liking this brand. I have their switch, two of these WAPs, and getting ready to purchase a bunch of their security cameras. These are easy to install and set-up. I've had zero issues with them over the few months I've owned them and the signal is great, too. If you're having issues with your Wi-Fi signal in your home, don't get more routers or extenders. Get these and your problem will be solved. Of course, you'll need a switch (preferably with POE capabilities) to make them work and also be able to run cabling.

I do network and security infrastructure for a living and I cannot be more impressed by the Unifi line of access points. After struggling with every brand of commercial routers for 15 years trying to keep my 3 story home with up to 20 wifi devices and 6 people happy, I have success.
I started with the 3 pack of BGN AP's and it was transformational. I got maximum bandwidth on every floor and have yet to have an AP fail, boot, or stop handling traffic unless I asked for it to do so. Today I aded the ProAC Dual-Radio unit to the mix to get a bit better bandwidth in the main section of the house and to repurpose one of the lesser units to the garage for better outdoor coverage. The new unit is an order of magnitude faster and was adopted and provisioned in probably 1/3 the time of the older units. That isn't so much a problem as it is a statement of the improvement.
And did I mention bandwidth? Pretty much every iPhone, iPad, laptop and Kindle within connection range of the new AP is pulling over 90Mbps when my max Internet bandwidth is 105.
For the small investment in time and effort to learn the difference between a router and an Access Point you will not be disappointed.
Simply amazing.

Easy setup, easy to add additional access points. I'm glad that Ubiquiti moved to 48V PoE which is an industry PoE standard instead of their 24V PoE on older models.
My only complaint is that I wish the installation would have options to install it to a different location. I have to manually move things and create the shortcuts to have the software where I want it.

I am thrilled with this unit so much so that I'm buying three more. There's nothing more I can add that hasn't already been written in other reviews. If you want enterprise quality gear at consumer prices, this is an excellent choice. It works great, was fairly easy to setup (if you know a thing or two about WIFI networking--newbies might be a bit over their head) and it's been 100% reliable for over six months of constant usage.

Just fired this thing up and so far I like it. Devices connect quickly. Can be a little confusing for the uninitiated to configure and the management interface doesn't help much. The interface could use some work to be more user friendly, but otherwise does the job. Part of the possible confusion is that the management interface is designed to manage multiple devices (APs, switches, etc), which isn't a bad thing if you need this capability, but can confuse users that haven't dealt with this sort of management capability in the past. If I had one complaint it would be that the UniFi Controller sofware frequently errors with a failed to initialize message if left running idle. Restarting it fixes the problem, but it is annoying.
This is a PoE only device, so you must use a PoE injector or PoE switch if installing it. Fortunately the single pack comes with a PoE injector. The power cord on the injector could be longer (its about 24 inches), but this is not a show stopper. Also nice is the secondary Ethernet port for bridging with another AP.
Connection speeds have been good and my phone had no problem connecting to the 5G radio automatically (something that was a chore with the LinkSys AC wireless router I've been using.
Very good item
Although for some reason I could not see its broadcast on my pc, I used another household laptop and was able to configure this product well. I am pleased with the results and would buy another!

I am so glad I bought this over the rival product I was considering. My aging DIR-655 which was only 802.11n 2.4GHz only was crashing every so often. While that wasn't catastrophic because I was only using it for 2.4GHz WiFi and not routing (I have my own router that I will not give up, ever). I also needed to supplement this with a cheap $20 802.11ac upgrade mini AP. But this AP had certain limitations that made it just an interesting gimmick. Being 802.11ac, it was capable of speeds in excess of 100Mbps under ideal circumstances, but it's single ethernet uplink port being Fast Ethernet only (100Mbps) made it cap out wireless speeds in total to just under 100Mbps. Also it was 5GHz only, so only my most expensive or more recent devices could use it (but that was ok, because I bought it mostly for my phone and my wife's phone). But being "mini" it's builtin antennae had horrible range (on top of the already known limited range of 5GHz compared to 2.4GHz). So while when the main WiFi crashed, my Internet was still usable to the wired devices and my phone, it got annoying that the kids constantly asked me why I shut the WiFi off, when I hadn't.
So I started looking into replacing both units for a single newer, faster, and more reliable unit. I had worked with much older (802.11g only) versions of these several years ago at a job where they bought some upon recommendations a coworker and I had made. While I was not the one who ended up setting them up I was pleased with the overall operation and range. So naturally I've always remained interested in them, but they were always too expensive for me to justify buying them for personal use.
But now a friend recommended Google WiFi, which did a similar 3 AP setup. I also liked that I could just buy one. But then I realized I could buy just 1 of the Ubiquiti Unifi. And both turned out to be 802.11b/g/n/a/ac. And both were priced the same (within a $1 of each other when I bought this). Though the Google WiFi claimed a SUBSTANTIALLY higher range than the Ubiquiti Unifi (though that claim was also WAY higher than many other wireless routers that were believable so it was immediately suspect). I read many recent reviews that did say the Google WiFi had awesome range (though nothing likely close to the 3x difference compared to this unit). But one thing the reviews all agreed upon is that despite the range, it was NOT the fastest wireless single they tested in a group of mesh systems.
What killed it for me was when I did more research it came out that the Google WiFi systems are actually a router and while it is capable of being put into what they call "bridged" mode, where it essentially behaves just as a regular Access Point only WiFi device with no routing functionality... You end up loosing most of the cool functionality they show in the videos. That made it pointless, as being a Systems Engineer by profession, I demand more control of my systems. There was also the uncool tendency of Google just abandoning a project they feel isn't worth it anymore for them (either it's not making them any money or who knows, maybe they just lost interest). While I've had a great experience with my two (1 first gen, 2nd newer) Chromecast, I've had other Google products that become fundamentally defunct due to Google choosing to no longer support them way before I feel I am done with the device. And something like my WiFi I typically buy and it gets used for 5 years or so, I wasn't comfortable with the very real possibility of Google abandoning it just because THEY felt it was too old, before I felt the same way.
So I pulled the trigger and bought one of these instead of the Google WiFi. After receiving it and setting it up, I have to say I couldn't be happier. Google WiFi may be a great product, but I feel it's more for the typical "hipster" masses than for an Engineer like me. I will definitely say that while the Ubiquiti Unifi isn't enterprise Cisco type of complexity to setup, but it is definitely more advanced than your average person who doesn't consider themselves computer savvy. While this does require software to setup and run these APs, it is different in that it runs more as a server software that can be made to run all the time to control these. However, it gives you the flexibility to install this anywhere you want, so you don't have to have it installed as a piece of server software on your desktop, and maybe install it on a file server you may have on your network if you prefer (I'm thinking of doing it on a raspberry Pi myself). Also the software doesn't need to be running all the time for the AP to function, just to make changes, or do monitoring of the APs. So for now I just fire it up when I need to make a change.
Range. I don't know if the Google WiFi would have really blown this thing out of the water, but all I can say is, for me, for what I wanted, this thing gets 5 stars in range, definitely better than my previous setup. I get signal throughout my whole 1100sqft apartment.
Speed. I finally get the full speed of my 150+Mbps Internet connection even from a room or two away on the WiFi!!! That previously required a wired connection to do! 5 stars here again. I am definitely impressed at this point.
Configuration options. Again, this thing is in between enterprise and home office, definitely more advanced than the typical unit, but not so daunting that I believe even tech savvy types could easily figure out most things. If you don't understand computers much, then yes, this is not for you. It has plenty of options, and flexibility in how you set it up, that it empowers you to set your network up as you see fit to fit YOUR needs. Not what most companies believe you do with your computers/devices.
In the end I literally have ZERO complaints about this thing. I am super ecstatic I went with this instead of something else possibly even more expensive offering functionality I didn't even really need. More than highly recommended if you really just need a good high quality Access Point.

Router reception in my parents house is awful so this was their Christmas gift. Easy to set up and connect devices. Now there's WiFi on the other side of the house.
So it prompted me to buy my own. I have Netflix through my Blu Ray players and it hasn't worked in a year. For some reason they couldn't maintain connection with my new router. It worked for few months, but stopped working after sometime. My router range was not good enough so thought to buy extender than replacing router, should have replaced my router. This product is not good.

I purchased this as I needed to extend range on my Apple Time Capsule router. My house is 3600 square feet plus a 1500 square feet finished basement. The router is placed in a corner of the house where internet is not really needed. Rather then trying to re-wire my house, I opted to get this range extender. It was placed about 20 feet from the router in the kitchen. Service was usually ok in the living room (next to the kitchen), but rarley worked upstairs, especially in the rooms farthest from the router and extender. I was also constantly going into settings on my iPhone and iPad to get the "best" signal as extenders are "separate" from the main router. It did not work for my needs and would not recommend you purchase. Mesh networks are now available and recommend if you have the money to go with an Amplifi HD or Netgear Orbi, especially if you have a larger home and do not want or need direct Ethernet ports.
terrible no support web page nt working for setup

I bought this but ended up returning it. It didn't do much for my network stability issues. I ended up getting a 50ft ethernet cable, and it solved my problems.I have to say though that the setup was very easy and it was quite convenient to have a separate wifi network to connect to for it.

Just set this up yesterday, Works great! I wish I would have done this long ago! Set up was very easy! products.name: Roku Premiere+ Streaming Media Player

detail.comments: This product soundly does what it was designed to do and is easy to install. But, the user interface is a little tedious to use.

We love our Roku!! Finally got rid of that overpriced satellite subscription!!! Yes you have to learn something new, but it's not difficult. My little grandson can already tell you what channel he wants you to put it on. Plus we put up an outdoor antenna and get 25 channels from that. There is no limit to what you can watch!
This is my 2nd Roku. My previous was a 2. The difference in graffics and processing is amazing. The apps are better too. I loved my last Roku and this one has not disappointed.

I do like the product. I upgraded from a Roku 3 after buying a 4k TV. Easy to setup. Great content availability. But it has lip sync issues. This is something Roku needs to fix soon. There is a work around though. Change the audio out from 'DolbyD/DTS' to 'DolbyD'. That seemed to solve the issue for me. I would like my DTS audio back. Roku needs to update firmware to fix this problem. If they fix this, I will move this up to 5 stars.
We have 4 Roku devices in our home. The video quality from this unit is very noticeable compared to the Roku 2 it replaced. The ethernet jack is a real plus for streaming.
Sound from remote headphone jack mutes rapidly on and off too often. No problem when listening from headphone connected to TV

I was going to buy the Amazon Fire TV but when I did a little more research I found out amazon doesn't have the Vudu app and seeing as how all my digital movie content is with Vudu I was not willing to sacrifice that. (I was using a Playstation 4 to stream before) SO... I looked into Roku and since they had the Vudu app and everything else I could want (plus they have the amazon video app) I was sold. The only thing left was to decide which model I wanted to go with. Basically I chose the premier+ so I could plug my ether net cord into it. I have WiFi but I like the speed and reliability of a direct connection. I set this up quickly and easily. It's super user friendly and has everything I need. I'm very happy with my decision to go with Roku!
If they can not get the sync straightened out on this, I will be returning it ASAP. Amazon and Netflix shows are a joke, My old Roku did not have this problem.
I find Ruco Much better then Apple or Amazon Fire Stick, I have all 3, and now use only Ruco
have 2 more so I wouldn't order if I didn't like them.
This is great IF YOU HAVE FAST INTERNET!

Pros
Performance: Great
Selection: Soooo much without even live TV to watch
Price: Saving me about $150/mo compared to my old cable bill. ATT discounted my internet so it did not go up in price since I have my cell phones through them. So it is worth it in one month!
Cons
Navigation is still a little odd. I have to do multiple clicks to get my shows I tag... that should be the first thing I see.
I also get a little confused about what I have new episodes in and what I do not until I drill in to the show page
Some things come up right away, others like "The Bachelor" come up days or a week later which ticked my wife off a bit. ;)
The remote does nothing to control TV volume. Had to purchase a sideclick to assist with that.

Here is hint. To really make use of the AC chip you need the Roku to see 5Ghz channels, which it may not do out of the box. You will need to go into your router setting and adjust 5Ghz from 80hz to 40hz. Super easy to do, and once done you can enjoy the speed you bought this thing for. if don't then you are only using standard N speeds and bandwidth. The upgraded iphone functionality is a nice feature.from the Roku 3.

It's awful, too time consuming, looking for a channel to watch. It's a money pit.... Need more live streaming channels. Set it and walk away.
I don't like CNN, or The Alphabet channels or the news channels, It's just snippets. I'm very surprised that it has made it this far...
Love Roku products. The micro sd slot and Ethernet port are great features.

Good: Simple clean home screen.
Bad: Terrible Playstation Vue app. Roku doesn't run the full version of the app which runs on other devices like Amazon Fire.
I returned it after 5 minutes of use.
Easy setup. I had experience with a previous roku series. Once my channels were downloaded, I was up and running. Great product.

I am highly impressed with this. Its faster than my old Roku 2 that I've had for years. I own a Apple TV, Roku 2, and a Chromecast and this is by far the best one out of all of them. You won't be disappointed with it!
Product received as described on time. Works great with 4K HDR TV
The Roku is great, which PS Vue would develop the guide for Roku

Last update 4-5-2017: After going back and forth between Roku and Rovio aka Angry Birds on my issue , (I was told to contact Rovio as Roku could not do anything) I received this sad email from Rovio:
Apr 5, 18:04 EEST
Hello there,
thank you for reaching out to us. Unfortunately, we have ended the distribution of our games on Roku platform on the 31st of August 2014. As a result, our games are no longer available on Roku. We hope you get a chance to play the games on another platform.
As long as you have those games installed, they will remain available for you to play, but they can no longer be purchased. We apologize for the inconvenience caused and hope this clarifies things.
Best regards,
Tadeusz
Rovio Support Team
*** So folks, if you still have a working Roku 2 XS or a Roku 3, keep those as all the Angry Birds games work on them. EVEN if you paid for these Angry Birds games, they will NOT carry over to the NEW Roku models even though all the other games you may have purchased for the Roku 2XS or Roku 3 carry over to the NEW Roku models (as mine have) just NOT the Angry Birds games that you got for FREE or purchased. *** I tried.. for my son with Autism, and hoping for LESS clutter. Good thing I still own 4 Roku 2XS's!
UPDATE 4/4/2017:
After a lot of research, I found out that the Angry Birds Game license with ROKU has expired and this game is only found on the original Roku 2XS models now. After further research, I found that I can add a vanity code and PURCHASE Angry Birds Rio and Angry Birds Seasons for $4.99 each. Which I did today. However, these 2 Angry Birds games I purchased (like others I have bought) only show up on my ROKU 2 XS's and not on my Roku Premier + or my Roku Ultra. Very frustrating because the past games I have purchased for my Roku 2XS's all show up on the new Roku Models, but not the Angry Birds Rio or Angry Birds Seasons. **knocking off another star!**
-----
I own 4 Roku 2XS (since 2013) and they've worked great up until Dec. 2016, when now watching a video via Amazon Prime or Youtube or SlingTV, they all now RE-BOOT within 60 minutes when they never had a problem prior to Dec 2016. No fix for this strange problem and it coincidentally seems maybe Roku is forcing us to buy the NEWER models? Regardless, I plunged in and bought 2 replacements for 2 of my Roku 2 XS's.
One the Roku Premier+ and the other a Roku Ultra both via Amazon. Both work great (so far) while watching movies for over 60 minutes, but my only BIG GRIPE is they have taken away the basic ANGRY BIRDS GAME (offered free with the ROKU 2XS) It is not offered free or for purchase at all on the newer ROKU Models! Sure they have the other games we've purchased with the Roku 2XS's now brought over to my new ROKU models as well as some other games for free and for purchase, but my problem is the NEW ROKU MODELS are missing the ANGRY BIRDS GAME. It is just not there for us now. The NEW ROKU models are very capable of handling the basic Angry Birds Game. So why isn't it offered?
My one 13 yr old twin son has Autism. HE LOVES this game! He plays it alone, and the best part is that he PLAYS WITH OTHER FAMILY MEMBERS with this awesome game. I've messaged ROKU via Facebook how this very simple fun family game should be brought back to the NEWER ROKU Models. If the old Roku 2XS's can handle the Angry Birds game, certainly the new Roku Models can.
I can't post my petition link on this issue here with my Amazon review, but maybe others out there can contact ROKU about bringing the Angry Birds Game back to the new ROKU models via email, twitter, or FB on this issue that would be great!
If Roku brings back this FUN FAMILY GAME (even if I have to purchase it) , I will raise my rating stars to 5.

Take this with a grain of salt. I usually don't review something I only owned for a week or so.. But I don't get the smoothness everyone is talking about. Especially on apps that the Premiere+ have that My Fire TV, and Shield TV have. Slow, sluggish, not nice to look at etc. I get such a better experience on the other devices. Especially the Fire TV. In my view that's the Golden rule of devices right now..

I have a Samsung 60" TV with 1080p only, i have been using a Roku 3 for the last 4 years. This new premier+ is much faster and the picture is a lot clearer. Also i noticed the improved audio selection seems to make my surround sound sound much better. Minimal improvements, but i think it was well worth the nominal fee.
Excellent device. Works just as advertised. Thank you Roku for helping me cut the cord.

Much better than my previous Roku. Remote is more ergonomic and sits in the hand nicely. Headphone feature is a lifesaver if I want to watch tv at times when something else is going on in the house like kids doing schoolwork or someone wants to read and I want to watch a movie.

While the player works fine, my 1 star rating is for the customer service provided by Roku. There is absolutely no way to contact them by phone. I tried web sites, instructions in the Roku box, etc. I had a minor problem==fixed it myself finally. But could have saved myself a whole lot of time by talking to an "expert" at Roku. It is quite obvious to me they were not interested in me as a customer, but more about saving money by not having someone available by phone to assist you. Next time I am going to review more closely other devices doing the same task as this Roku and remember this experience. If your phone number is published somewhere, I am taking a Donald Trump. No apology, it should have been easier to find!

I've had Roku since the beginning as well as AppleTV and Google Chromecast. Now I only use Roku as it supports virtually any channel while I found that Google Chromecast wasn't ideal as it was great from casting but not streaming unless you used a tablet or smartphone. While I've been a Apple products user for many decades, I found that Apple TV didn't allow for Amazon, a competitor, as well as some other channels. Roku allows you to have far more channels than you can ever imagine plus you can also add what they call Private Channels, not necessarily porn, but other channels that aren't listed in their control box.

I've been using the older Roku3 for about 2 years and it was great. We bought a new 4k tv so I decided to also buy the new Roku4 premiere plus which supports 4k video. That's the end of the improvements over the Roku3. As MANY other people have posted, there is a terrible audio syncing issue with this device. Netflix seems ok, but Plex is unwatchable. I've tried connecting the roku directly to the TV and I've tried connecting it through my Yamaha receiver. The audio is out of sync on the same videos and by the same amount of time for both methods. I've tried changing the audio settings in the roku as well as my receiver; some settings work better than others but none of them are acceptable. Movies with DTS audio are the by far the worst. The audio plays about 1 second ahead of the video. Dolby and DTS-MA are both a little out of sync. This is unusable.
I can play netflix and plex through my TV's apps and the same programs all play perfect, so it's not source videos. I wanted the roku because the plex app has additional functions not available through my tv's version of the app. I'll wait a little bit for an answer, but this thing is going to be returned.

The good:
It does what it is supposed to do. Overall no better or worse than any other device of the same kind. If you are looking for a device to access your Netflix/Hulu/Amazon Prime stuff this will do it fine.
The bad:
If you are a person that does not care about privacy or being forced to do things then there is no bad. However if you, like me, care about privacy and don't like being forced to do things then you won't like it.
1. You HAVE to sign up for a Roku account. You cannot access the device if you do not.
I don't see why I need a Roku account to access my Netflix account. I don't need a Samsung account to use my Samsung bluray player that also allows me to access my Netflix account. The Roku box is just a door stop if you don't sign up for a Roku account.
2. You are forced to enter a credit card in order to get a Roku account.
Why? If I have no intention of buying anything through Roku why do then need to have my CC number? If I am only using it to access other third party apps such as Netflix or Hulu then why does Roku need my CC info?
3. It needs your phone number to set up a Roku account.
Again, why? No other devices needs this info just to use it to access third party stuff.
So bottom line is that if you don't mind this stuff then it is OK; no better or worse then other options. Since I do mind this stuff I think I will stick with my Amazon FireTV or my Samsung bkuray player which are not as nosy.
[True my Amazon FireTV requires stuff but I already have Amazon Prime so they have all that anyway. Likewise if Netflix had a box. But I was hoping that Roku, having no relation to any of these companies would be more like the Samsung box in that it just lets you do stuff without asking anything for itself. So better and perhaps more private than the others. Instead it is even more nosy.]

I own 4 roku devices, and was hoping to make this model my 5th. Unfortunately, there exists a bug in the current FW which causes the audio to be out of sync when playing DTS audio output to a compatible receiver. Roku has publicly acknowledge the existence of this bug in their forums, but there is currently no ETA on when the fix will arrive. 7.5.1 was supposed to fix the issue, but unfortunately for me it did not.
Until this bug is fixed, I am giving this product a 1 star review.
TL;DR buy a Roku 3 or 4. They are rock solid, this and the ultra are not.

products.name: ARRIS SURFboard SB6190 DOCSIS 3.0 Cable Modem - Retail Packaging - White

detail.comments: Fast setup, great router very fast with 100 mbps service

Stopped working tonight after four months. Have to return it to where I bought it, which means a 35 mile round trip and a waste of a couple of hours on top of the hours I've spent on the phone with Comcast tonight trying to figure out if it was there service or the modem. Was going on and off all night. Maybe I got a lemon, but I would never buy this brand again.

Someone explain to me why I need to keep buying these things every few years. What are they actually doing and why are they pushed so hard they immently fail every time? How can we move to a cable-less environment with this single point of failure......that ultimately sits above another single point of failure, the router. Racket. 1 star, but deserves 0.
Have to reboot the router multiple times a day as the internet cuts out. Terrible product. I can't believe I paid as much as I did for this garbage.
Hooked it up to my comcast cable and both download and upload speeds drastically decreased from the modem that Comcast provides.
Works well. Is awesome

Sorry to say I could never get it to connect to internet. Tried many times. Tech brought a different modem with him. Hooked it up and instantly worked. He said for some reason Surfboard Modems and Comcast sometimes have difficulty connecting. I am not patient enough to send back and try another model. I work at home and need reliable service. For now I will rent.
Helped increase my internet
Wow! Constant Time Warner problems cleared up when upgraded to this model. More power than TW provides, but is consistent.

Beware: There are latency issues concerning this, and any modem that is using the Intel Puma6 Processor. The issue was first reported on in depth by the many technical users on DSL Reports back in December 2016. Your ISP may have already pushed out a Firmware upgrade dealing with this known latency issue, and especially users with 1GB speeds. Do NOT purchase this unless and until Arris and Intel have provided the firmware upgrade to your ISP and/or your ISP has verified to you that the firmware upgrade has been pushed out for this model. The SB 6183 has been tested and does not have this issue. If you're a gamer, latency is not a good thing. Do your homework on this purchase! This applies to ANY make/model that utilizes the Intel Puma6 processor/chipset. Go with something that is Broadcom based to avoid this. As of this writing, no firmware update has been provided to ISPs by Intel. In fact, Intel has yet to acknowledge a problem, when it has been confirmed by many SB6190 users.
Product meets all expectations. This modem has worked perfectly right out of the box with very little time spent on setting it up. I would recommend this modem.

Works very well compared to the modems provided by Charter. The modem we were given by charter use to lose its connection with charter every 3 or 4 months. Simple reboot would fix it. But as time went by, this would happen more and more frequently. Until one day it no longer worked. I purchased this modem, installed it and called charter to have them provision it in to their system. Once done it has been perfect. No drops, no reboots, and speeds are a fair bit faster with this modem than with the one charter gave us.

Great little unit. Actually increased my promised speed in my area. I do some serious gaming, streaming, netflixing, and uploading and this thing handles it all like a champ. Had it for over a year now and never once had a problem with it. If you are a heavy user, this is the modem for you.

Thank you so much! As described and shipped perfectly.
Defiantly happy to buy from again!

After hooking it up and getting it activated with my cable company, I quickly found that the only speeds that are as advertised, are the hardwire speeds only. The Wi-Fi completely sucks. The range is terrible, and unreliable, and the speeds range from absolutely horrific, too good. Some speed test I'll get my for full 120 service, and others I might get only 13.... I have gotten 123 out of it once. On average don't expect to get more than 25 megs on wifi. Had I known that I wouldn't get my full speed I would have never bought in this product. Do not buy this if you want your Wi-Fi To work properly. I would've continue to pay the monthly service for my cable companies modem had I known that this modem with suck this bad. I never had an issue with Wi-Fi with my other modem. I would highly recommend staying with what you have with your current cable company if you want your Wi-Fi speeds to be as they are now. The advertisement this box is a complete lie. You will not get full speed on this thing. This is the first time I've ever given a bad review on a product. I am very disappointed.

This is one of the worst products I have ever purchased. In a 700 square foot studio, I am not able to hold a consistent wifi connection on multiple types of devices. I called Arris support and their solution is to blame the cable company. My solution: buy a crappy $25 router, which is working perfectly for streaming, downloading, etc. My suggestion: do your research and thoroughly test this very expensive paperweight so you can return it when your devices start dropping the wifi connection.
I like it so much I'm getting another for a second house. No downtime since installed 3 weeks ago.

Works well with my cable isp. Easy to set up.
Works perfectly

Nice
Does the job!
Works as expected

products.name: TP-Link Archer C7 Wireless Dual Band Gigabit Router (AC1750)

detail.comments:
The 5Ghz network seems to disappear within a day of rebooting.
The USB is only 2.0 (advertised, but 3.0 would be nice) and does not support our 4TB external hard drive (ExFAT formatted). Not sure what max size / formatting is supported.

I was suffering from horrible Wifi signal at home and low width band. I would always lose Wifi signal and had difficulty connecting multiple devices at once. Ever since I've had the TP-Link Archer C7 I have not had that problem. I love it! We no longer have dropped signal and we get Wi-fi throughout the entire house. Now I feel like I'm living in the 21st Century. Definitely worth every penny.

This router was working gorgeously for about a year and two months for me. I purposely purchased this router, which was fairly expensive at the time, because I wanted a router that would be able to broadcast a strong WIFI signal throughout my 2-story house. Simply: I was looking for quality. If you had asked me what I thought about this router anytime within the first year and two months of using it, I would have said "great, no problems. 5 stars."
Sadly, it looks like this product isn't designed to span to 2 years or past that. After a year and two months, the WIFI broadcasting has become dramatically weaker. From my 100+ mbps internet connection (speed confirmed with wired ethernet connections), I will now only receive up to 40 mbps if my wireless device is within 10 feet of the WIFI Router. Once I am 20 feet away, my WIFI speed is reduced down to 4 mbps. Anything beyond 20 feet is drastically slower (think cellular phone 2G speeds) or unusable. At 30 feet away, using my cell phone's internet as a hotspot is significantly faster than the internet speed I would get from the WIFI Router.
I've tried resetting the router, updating the firmware, changing the settings to default, unplugging it, relocating the router -- just about everything you can imagine. But for whatever reason the router's WIFI speed broadcast has become unusable if you're more than 20 feet away from it.
I would not recommend this router.

I finally got tired of the Centurylink modem-router combo unit we've been getting by with for a few years and decided to split the two functions. What a difference it made and I'm sorry I didn't do it long before now. The Centurylink unit is in bridge mode now and the TP-Link handles the wi-fi. I get much better connection speed downstairs and no dropouts. My wired speedtest download is 22.8 Mbps through a 20 Mbps service and 22.2 through the wi-fi downstairs in the far corner of the house. I'm quite happy with this purchase.

Excellent router. Super fast set up, great website to work with and make adjustments to settings. So far no problems at all.
I am very happy with this router. A little bigger than I expected, but does not take up too much space. Very impressive looking.
finally a product to fix the weak products givin to you bye your cable company
Great product thanks.
It didn't work for us and we had to return in. But, we were told we just needed a USB wifi card which we did purchase and that did work.

Have had many routers over the past couple years and decided to give this one the go, for whatever reason this router even when I updated the firmware to the latest version for the appropriate model v2 just constantly drops my download speed to 1Mbps.I pay for 80Mbps down and get it right after I reset the router for about 10 minutes then like clockwork it drops back down to 1mbps. Speed runs fine and never drops when I have my computer hardwired into the modem.
No reliable at ALL. Don't buy

After about 1.5 years of use and different firmware versions, I cannot recommend this router. When it works, it works exactly to spec. The problem is the sporadic outages (wired + wireless) 1-3 times a day, with no warning. Power cycling always fixes the issue, so no huge troubleshooting headaches there. Regardless, resetting the router multiple times a day should not be a part of anyone's routine. I'd look elsewhere for a good cheap router.

I've used this for several months now for my 1000 down 500 up fiber connection. It's worked well: I game a lot and have about the least amount of lag possible considering the distance to the server I play on, and I seldom experience spikes. Wifi seems to work great too but I don't use it for gaming.
The only problem I have is that I can't seem to get anywhere near 1000 down speeds unless I turn off the spi firewall, I suppose this thing just doesn't have the processing power to route 1000 mpbs with spi enabled: it seems to average no more than 300 mbps up and down with it on.

This router handles everything. Multiple PS4's at one time, work VPN, Apple TV streaming, etc. This replaced a multiple Apple AirPort Extreme setup in a three story 4500 sq. Foot house. Night and day difference.
Became unusable after I changed a setting. Customer service was a nightmare - TP-Link doesn't care about their customers very much.
Excellent router, signal is bullet proof.
Does what I ask it to do without complaint. Has great uptime, great range, and great speeds.
Lots of speed. Finicky at the outset. Doesn't want to let go of it's default password

It came in a nice box. That's the only good thing about the Version 1 router I can say. This version is well known for it's problems, Go oneline and punch in the name. Your supplier should remove all the version 1 s off the shelf and recycle the parts, I had this unit for 3 hours before I shipped it back. Buyer beware!! The version 2 is much better, bugs all worked out.
Works Good
Good range. Easy to set up.

NOTE: This review is for the TP-Link AC3150 VERSION 2, released 1st QTR 2017.
This replaces my nearly three year old Linksys AC1900 router which has been a good performer, but I recently upgraded to 100 Mbps download/10 Mbps upload speeds and wanted to make sure I had a modem with the latest protocols to handle everything smoothly. We are also considering upgrading to the 300/30 tier later in the year, so we wanted to make sure the router could handle that comfortably as well.
Installation was quick and painless and it recognized our existing connections. We have several printers, laptops, desktops, tablets, smartphones, and a smart UHD TV connected to the device, and with the exception of the Brother printer which required some reconfiguration, everything is working great. One thing I noticed immediately is Netflix 4K and HD streaming is SO MUCH SMOOTHER, especially when another person is watching 4K videos on YouTube at the same time. With the old Linksys AC1900 router we would always have buffering delays on one or both devices.
Signal strength on each device is 3 to 5 bars, which is about the same or maybe slightly improved over the old router. We have the router in about the center of our apartment which is fairly long and narrow but not huge, so I'm sure we're not testing the limit of the AC3150's range.
Amazon still sells the first generation TP-Link AC3150 VERSION 1 (released 1st QTR 2016) TP-Link AC3150 Wireless Wi-Fi Gigabit Router with XStream Processing, NitroQAM, Smart Connect (Archer C3150 V1), and at the time of this review it sells for $50 less than the current model. In this new Version 2 device, TP-Link claims to have made improvements to the MU-MIMO functionality: "...(it) has been fine-tuned for better performance, providing more than twice the throughput across multiple MU-MIMO devices." You will have to decide for yourself if that feature improvement is worth the extra cost.
For us the TP-Link AC3150 V2 is a big improvement over our old router. If you have the first generation of the AC3150 I see no compelling reason to upgrade, but if your router is more than a few years old you are likely to see a performance improvement with this new model.
**** 4 STARS - HIGHLY RECOMMENDED! ****

This cure all my router problems that I was experiencing with my outdated netgear and a repeater. Now just one router and I have it placed in my workshop office. It covers all of it plus my entire home. I am very pleased.

The router served its purpose with minimal issues. I used it for 4 months and only had to reset a few times. What makes this only 2 stars is the customer support. You are calling another country, not only was the English hard to understand the connection was horrible. I called needing direction on changing the router channel and I could not hear her over a beeping noise. When I asked her about it she told me to call back later! .When I called back the beeping was gone but deciphering what the lady was saying was extremely difficult for me.
works great at my house

But whenever we're both on and all the other person is doing is just facebook stalking it'll quit and need a restart.
