So overall the speed is a huge upgrade but losing total internet access at random is very frustrating to an online gamer. Not sure what i should do with it as it only has this issue when both of us are online. I'm disappointed with its reliability
This works well, 2.5 works slower but longer ranges, the 5 is super fast but shorter range. I live on an acre and get reception at the back of the yard!
Wish parental controls schedule can be set to smaller intervals, not one hour.
Worked fine the first week. After the first week all the devices started to lose connections. The router needed to be restarted often.

It doesn't get nearly as much coverage as advertised. We've got a pretty sizeable house and the router is placed well in a spot where connectivity is ideal, but with a 100mb connection, the wifi drags, and for some reason it's wired ports also get poor connection. I've tried am alternate router bc I thought I was losing it, but no. Disappointed after a year. I'll be moving on.
Easy set up. Works much better than my old router and has better range. Great value!

products.name: Orbi Home WiFi System. Up to 5000sqft AC3000 Tri-Band WiFi (RBK50) By NETGEAR [WiFi Router & Satellite]

detail.comments:
I have had a lot routers over the years. No matter what brand I used there was always some place in the house the signal was poor and connection was intermittent. I was skeptical about the Orbi but read the reviews good and bad. I think the price was a bit too high but decided to give it a try knowing Amazon would take it back if it wasn't going to work for my purposes. My house is approximately 2300 square feet and has lots of walls.
I purchased Orbi December 10, 2016. I waited to write a review so I could see how Orbi was going to work.
When it arrived the installation went fairly smooth and was easy. Had a little difficulty in updating the satellite's firmware but figured it out and got it done. Once it was up, I have full signal throughout my house including the areas where the signal was poor. Simply amazing.
What I like is that it uses a separate wireless band for connecting the two units. It uses one SSID and chooses the best band for your device that you are connecting. I haven't had any connection issues and has been running great.
Overall, I would recommend this to anyone but it is pricey. I just hope the unit lasts a long time. I did purchase a warranty just in case.

DISCLAIMER: This is actually a review of Netgear warranty/support, not the product.
This system has the same one-year Netgear warranty which covered my 16-month-old Nighthawk X8. It also is/was cutting edge, until it died suddenly last night, which is why I'm looking at replacements. I would have been willing to consider Orbi if it had a longer warranty, but no such luck.
Netgear DOES NOT EVEN ACCEPT EMAILS for product issues after the warranty expires, it points you at the community and paid support when all I have is a question.
Apologies for appearing to dis the product itself, but I did want to alert customers impressed by its 'wow' specs that a brick is a brick, and dead electronics have no specs, they're just an indication of a bad investment. I'll be looking at other offerings.

I am speechless! Installed in less than 10 minutes. No connection problems. All this after spending 6 hours trying to get a new Netegear router/extender system to work properly - finally sent it back and got an ORBI. This is the best system I have had period.Well worth the price.

Great product that does as advertised.
Nice Wifi unit , wish they had a better interface page to configure unit , I miss my Asus interface, but I'm getting great wifi coverage.

I know $300 is a lot of money but just bite the bullet. This finally solved the problem, I had tried 3 other devices in the past that only offered partial relief. Old house, 4 levels, router on top floor, could never get good coverage in entire house despite buying high speed from my ISP. I've never had an problem online including video anywhere in the house since I started using Orbi and my kids have also stopped complaining about it.

I prefer to believe this modem is allowing that. Not to mention this thing has amazing ventilation and I can't imagine the line getting bottle necked between myself and my two other roommates.

This only supports gigabit ethernet LAN side. If you plug in any 100mpbs device the modem won't even return a ping (to the modem itself). The ethernet traffic light correctly lights amber and shows traffic, but nothing gets through. This was not revealed in the documentation or advertisement. Calling Netgear support resulted in their blaming Comcast (because they got SNR and dbmv confused from the status page and wouldn't admit it). Even when I explained the problem the blamed Comcast. The direct evidence is that I connected a gigabit computer to a gigabit hub to this modem. It was fine. The I added a 100mpbs device to the hub and everything stopped working, including the gigabit computer. Various other device and cable combinations eliminated other possible sources of failures.
Outside of that it works well at a good price, but it took a while to debug and the purchase of another router. I'm giving it two stars not for lack of functionality but rather lack of revelation and bad tech support.
The FLASH!

Despite being a network administrator that deals with far more complex wireless, routing, switching, security appliances, etc I don't tend to spend a lot of money for home networking equipment. I want my home network to deliver me the bandwidth package I purchase from my ISP to all my devices, and that's about it. I didn't want to keep the ISP provided wireless/security appliance as many ISP provided systems are now revoking access to assign custom DNS servers via DHCP. Cox, for example, won't allow this change and their DNS servers are SLOW, probably due to being overloaded. A big reason they're doing this is to attempt to prevent people from going with DNS services that block geolocation. Pair that with devices such as a Roku that also won't allow assigning custom DNS servers and you see the problem.
I'd like a Meraki setup because of advanced functions & VPN to my offices, but didn't want to fork out the cost... I'll probably eventually have my company provide it, but for now I just need a device to provide flexible wireless service from my ISP's modem. Outside of controlling my DNS via DHCP, I really don't need anything advanced at home, so I found a $30 TP-LINK that did just that... but also the wireless throughput was WEAK & inconsistent, despite switching channels & other means to avoid interference. I hopped back on Amazon and found the ASUS, which is a brand of various hardware that I've trusted for years... 12 hours later, it's in the Amazon locker. I get it home, 15 minutes later I have it setup with my preferred DNS with expected signal/throughput. It has far more advanced features that I may eventually tinker with, but for now, it does everything I need with ease.

Overall this has been one of the best routers I've owned. It's fairly stylish, performance and reliability are excellent for its price, and the included firmware is very feature-rich for a stock firmware. Beware though that as of the time of writing, it doesn't appear to be compatible with third party firmwares such as DD-WRT and Tomato, and the guy who writes the Merlin AsusWRT firmware says it will not be ported to this model. However, I really don't consider this lack of firmware diversity an issue, because it does offer a ton of functionality in the built-in firmware.

It seems some of these routers have hardware issues. I had the same problems a few other reviewers did: SSID of wireless network would disappear while wireless network lights on the device remained on as well as frequent disconnects even while SSID was still being broadcast. After exchanging for a new router, the problems went away and everything works great. Would have been 5 stars except for the defective router.

I'll start by saying Amazon's customer service on this has been amazing, but the router is faulty out of the box. The last few iterations of Asus firmware has been deeply flawed, frequent WAN disconnects regardless of settings. This router is new and has no Tomato or Merlin alternative supported firmware, so you are stuck with the single one ASUS gives you. Every 5-10 minutes the WAN disconnects for no reason, I've spent hours on the phone with ASUS and reading countless reports of other people online with the same issues with no resolution.
When it works, it's got great range and is very fast. But dropping internet every 10 minutes is unacceptable. I ended up ditching it and buying a TP-Link Archer C7. Avoid at all costs until ASUS gets a stable firmware instead of shipping this garbage.

We decided use it as a wireless extender and we did play around with the configuration way too much not because of this unit. The primary router was big-brother the AC88U. We were constantly losing the 5.0 channel off if it. Had we not been monitoring it we never would have noticed as when the 5.0 dropped on the AC88U (you could not even see the SSID being broadcast) it would fail over to this unit. We were observing devices connected to the weaker signal. If you google AC88U you will real all about 5.0 dropping. It is a problem that you can see on other manufacturers too. After much tweaking we now have a stable connection and bridging.

I have purchased literally hundreds of products on Amazon, but never felt the need to post a negative review until now. Despite following all instructions and spending several hours over 2 days, I could never get this router to connect to the internet. If you browse the other 1-star reviews, you'll see that this is a common problem.
I returned this router, and on the advice of a salesperson at a local electronics store, I purchased a Netgear router. Although I had some similar problems connecting at first, the key difference was the Netgear "Genie," software provided by Netgear that solved the connection problems and made the needed adjustments in the Ethernet and WiFi settings on my computer.
Unless you are EXTREMELY conversant with setting up a WiFi router, I would avoid TP-link products. Although they have software that is supposed to aid in set up, I could never get it to work properly or even save my settings! I recommend Netgear -- the Genie will save you a lot of headaches!

I take one-star Amazon reviews with a grain of salt, especially with something like wireless routers where there's a ton of factors that can go wrong (environment, user error, etc). I had a TP-Link router prior to this that had its WiFi die after about four years, but was otherwise solid. I have used some other TP-Link networking products with no issues, so I had no qualms trying out this router.
The wireless range and speed of this router were vastly improved over my old one. Really impressive, I could pull down good speeds all over my house. The admin interface was fairly intuitive. Great. Wired performance has been solid, and remains so.
A few weeks later I started getting some reliability problems with the WiFi. I tried lots of different settings tweaks - separated out the 5G with a different SSID which possibly helped, and I made sure the firmware was up-to-date. All the usual suspects. I go through with a SSID scanner to make sure I'm not trying to share the same channel as my neighbors. Everything seems okay.
About 2-3 weeks later (after the return window), we start getting the problem that is described in pretty much EVERY 1-star review: The WiFi will show up to devices, but is impossible to wirelessly connect to the router. (E.g., your SSID will show up on your computer with four bars, but your computer can't connect to it) Rebooting the router fixes it (usually). Needless to say, I am less than impressed with a box I have to reset every other day to get it to work correctly.
This problem is more and more frequent, and I decided to replace the router last week. This week I've finally started to see the other problem mentioned in the 1-star reviews: Reboots send me back to factory settings (including admin passwords and SSIDs) so now I have a router that needs to be rebooted all the time and that won't save my settings when I do.
My theory is that it's a heat management issue, but I'm officially done fooling with the AC1200. I'm off to search for a replacement, wish me luck.
** see also all the 1-star reviews on the other Amazon AC1200 listing

products.name: 1byone Amplified HDTV Antenna - 50 Mile Range with Detachable Amplifier USB Power Supply and 10ft Coax Cable

detail.comments: Damn fine antenna. You seriously do not need anything else. If it's more channels you want, just get cable, satellite or something that runs Kodi.
does not work....junk

Despite the many positive reviews, I found the signal quality to be severely lacking on this model. Given how poorly it was receiving all the local channels (every one of which is within 30 miles of my house), I took some notes and did comparisons with all three TVs in my house in different locations. I compared it to the Antennas Direct 50 Mile Range Clearstream Eclipse Amplified Indoor HDTV Antenna, White/Black (ECL-A) (which I ordered shortly after due to the poor coverage) and, before that arrived, I also tested out a control in the form of a 6' piece of coaxial cable, plugged into nothing.The piece of coaxial cable, while picking up very few channels, did almost as well as the 1byone in almost all cases. The other antenna got nearly double the channels, in most cases, and the signal on all channels was improved. So, despite the popularity, you might want to do some more research and see if you can find actual reviews with testing and rankings of models, as the tastes of Amazon reviewers leaves a lot to be desired, especially in a suburban setting.
Doesnt work dont buy it
the antenna works ok but 50 mi range is a joke.
It picked up 30 additional channels that my expensive one had not and it's the same range.

Initially I loved this antenna. It picked up 48 OTA channels, half of them Spanish or Asian language channels, but 48!!! I first placed it beside the TV with the stand that you can buy separately and nada! zero! zilch! Then I hung it in the window and things got much better. I'm in a first floor apartment and the window is set 6 feet back from the patio front and overhung by the second floor balcony. 48!! Reception was very clear. Every so often the signal would weaken causing 3 to 4 seconds of pixelation. I resolved that by plugging the USB powered amplifier into a power strip rather than the TV's USB. Maybe the TV doesn't supply enough continuous power to the USB ports? I don't know. Wasn't a big deal and I didn't pursue the issue.
Then... it fell. About 3 feet and hit the sill. The antenna is made of very rigid plastic, not at all bendable. So when it fell a small piece of that plastic in the corner broke off. Mind you I had used the 3M adhesive included with the product. I thought that little piece wouldn't affect reception because it's housing and not the internal antenna. It worked, off and on, for the rest of the day but the next morning... dead. I rescanned for channels and nothing. I returned it and bought the
Winegard FlatWave Amped 50 mile range antenna. The construction is a lot better. It picked up 12 less channels, all Spanish language, but I receive the 8 OTA channels I wanted without issue.
It stopped working after 4 days.

Clearly junk and not worth the hassle of sending back because parts are missing.
I would not recommend this as a deal.
If you like throwing money away then send it to me.

adhesive tape damaged my wall, wish it was easily removable

It may be a good product but we couldn't get any stations with it. We looked up how far the stations were from our house and the furthest one was 17 miles from our location. We live just outside the city and not In a rural area.
This is awesome! I didn't have very high expectations because I live in the mountains of Colorado but it gives me a great picture and more channels than I had with a rooftop antenna.

I have my for 2 months and the reason I give it a 3 star is because it's so sensitive that you don't even have to push in any buttons if you just touch it by accident or bang on it turns all the opponents on and it takes for ever to turn off kodi when you trying to exit kodi it takes a good 20 or 30 seconds to shut off for those reasons it his very frustrating it is not any better than other boxes that I had the review that I read they all made it sound it is the tv box to have it way above the rest I don't find that at all.

The design is buggy and not reliable. When it breaks, customer service will tell you it’s software on your PC rather than replace a defective unit. I would not recommend this device. After working for 6 weeks flawlessly, Gamestream stopped being able to access my computer to stream games.
Setup:
• PC connected directly to WLAN through Ethernet
• Shield connected to same WLAN on 5G band (issue same on 2.4 G band)
• Card: Nvidia Geforce GTX 1070 (MSI)
• Windows 10
Here is my timeline.
• Purchased Nvidia Shield through Amazon on 2/2/17.
• Shield was delivered on 2/4/17
• Installed Shield on approximately 2/4/17
• Shield and Gamestream from my PC ran great until I returned from a 3 week business trip on (2/26-3/17).
• Contacted Nvidia to resolve on this on 3/18
• Spent combined 2.5 hours with Shield technical service, I believe 3 levels of escalation were necessary.
• Nvidia claimed something had been installed on my computer that was now blocking access (nothing was installed on my computer during the 3 weeks, it was turned off).
• Using Acronis, I restored my entire operating system to 1/27/17 (well before any issues had started) to check to see whether Shield would now work properly. If it was true something had been installed that was now an issue, the system should work.
• Reinstalled Geforce Experience, update Geforce Experience, verified correct Nvidia user name on both
• Tried various websites (Youtube, Pandora, etc) on Shield. All good
• Tried to Gamestream an installed game from my PC– nothing would work. Shield would perpetually display “Waking up” with a rotating green circular arrow.
The above should, based on Nvidia’s technical support, fully resolve the issue I experienced.

It's not perfect, but close enough for five stars. Tried this against a Steam Link for streaming games from my PC. The PC is connected to WiFi in another room. Played Far Cry 4 and Fallout 4. A few dropped signals with this and the Steam Link, but very few for the full length of both games. I'd say the Steam Link was a tad better holding the WiFi. However, this works with my old Logitech MX Air Mouse, and the Steam Link doesn't. Both worked with two different bluetooth keyboards and an XBox 360 controller. The Shield includes it's own game controller with just a couple different button locations from an Xbox 360 controller. It did get confused if my game crashed, and a restart got it going again.
I used the Plex App on it, and a couple other Android apps from the Google Play store and they worked great. The Plex app on this is different than on the Roku. I personally prefer the Roku version as it seems to have more ways to list shows.
I used it to stream some YouTube music videos and it worked well. However, for me it's about bringing my PC games into the living room, while leaving my PC at my desk.

Ordered from Amazon US and shipped to Australia.
I had to get an adapter for the plug, but no transformer required.
The Shield's UI is very snappy, great connectivity. Having quite considerable lag using GeforceNow game streaming service, but I think it's due in part to Australian ISPs general speeds, and also using a WiFi point on a different floor. Other media streaming is perfect, runs Kodi and Plex well.

perfect little Kodi box. A little expensive compared to other Android boxes but this one is worth every penny.
The only downfall is the remote in this version not being able to recharge. It ate through the battery in a just a few months, so I have purchased a new Bluetooth remote for it.

There is a lot to love about the 2017 Nvidia Shield TV console. It's not perfect, but for $199, it's an amazing machine and the perfect front end my media center.
Who is the Shield TV for? This device is perfect for cord cutters of all flavors. It's simple enough for non-geeks to plug in and start streaming Netflix, Amazon, Google Play, etc. If that's all you need, though, you might consider saving some money and going with either a Roku or Fire TV, but I will say that I prefer the interface of the Shield TV to either of those options. However, if you're like me, and a big nerd about this stuff, then forget all the other options: the Shield TV is the king. I'll get into some reasons (as well as some frustrations), but there are so many that I'm sure I'll forget some.
1. Ticks all the streaming boxes: Netflix, Amazon, Google, Hulu and everything else you can think of (except Apple, of course): Not only is it the only machine that can say that, but it does it right: 4K all around, and for Google, you get the entire Play Store ecosystem and an official (and slick) YouTube app. Most of these are also integrated to the point where you can do one search to expose content in several services (except Amazon Prime Video, that is still in its own silo).
2. Home media integrations: As someone with a large collection of digital media, this was a big one for me. The Shield TV has so many options for playing local and network files ranging in simplicity from plugging in a USB drive to hosting a Plex Media Center and lots of in-between options. Personally, I am using it as a Plex Media Client with my server still hosted on my PC, but I also use Kodi and have my media library on my PC mapped as a network storage location on the Shield, which then allows for my library to be accessed from Kodi. As long as you can get to the media, you can play it on the Shield TV one way or another. You can also plug in a USB 3.0 drive and use it as adopted storage for your Shield TV, which I recommend if you are going to be installing apps and games much. All of these capabilities work as expected, but I did encounter some error messages along the way. However, after a few tries, everything turned out OK.
3. Gaming: the gaming capabilities of the Shield TV are awesome, but confusing and sometimes unreliable. The simplest option is to install games from Google Play Games. Nvidia has even ported some PC games over to Android specifically for this purpose, but as long as the game works with a controller, you're pretty much good to go for Play Store games. Next, you have GeForce Now, which is like Netflix for games, and it rocks. The selection of games is a little small for now, but I found plenty that I liked. This is a great option for people without dedicated gaming rigs and even on my low-tier internet package, it was serviceable. Finally, there's Gamestream, which is my preferred way to play. In fact, I went and and bought a EVGA GeForce GTX 1050 Ti SC GAMING, 4GB GDDR5, DX12 OSD Support (PXOC) (04G-P4-6253-KR) just so I could do this. When it works, it's amazing, but so far I've found it only works on about half the games I want to play. For Example: Borderlands 2 is a "go", Mass Effect 3 is a "no-go".
4. Hardware: Speaking of gaming, the included controller is amazing (comparable to the XBox 360 controller which is very familiar to me). The remote is pretty good but not quite perfect: they took away the headphone jack, which is too bad. The volume control is a neat idea, but not responsive or obvious enough for me. Also, I wish the thing just had a power button. The integration of the IR blaster is awesome though: I love being able to turn my TV on and off with the device and control the volume of my receiver from the same little remote. They also axed some of the storage options for the non-pro model. I really wish that they had put in an extra USB port or something, especially when you're basically forced into using one of them for adopted storage. I don't have anything in the second port now, but it stresses me out to think I can only plug one more thing in, whatever that eventually is. The hardware is amazing where it counts though: it's super fast and looks great.
5. The Future! As fun and functional as the Shield TV is, there is the additional promise of the big update that incorporates Google Home functionality using the controller as the far-field microphone input. This, along with the Spot microphones which add additional interaction points to Google Home, will add a whole new dimension to the device. I can't wait for that!
Some buggy stuff:
1. The initial setup was harder than it should have been. There was a bug that prevented me from authenticating my Google account from my phone, as it tried to have me do. Then it failed to update after downloading the entire 1-gigabyte file, which it had to start over. Hopefully by the time you're reading this they've managed to iron out these details. Nothing kills your enthusiasm like running into bugs in the initial setup process.
2. I purchased the Samsung 128GB BAR (PLASTIC) USB 3.0 Flash Drive (MUF-128BC/AM) to use as adopted storage specifically because it was one of the few that were recommended by Nvidia for this purpose. However, getting it to work was a pain. First appeared to freeze during the process of formatting the drive and then it wouldn't be found or the format would be incorrect, I had to restart several times. Then it reported that the drive might be slow, which doesn't make sense because it's USB 3.0 and specifically recommended as the one you're supposed to use!

Not a good local media player. At all. The local library does not show you file names, just a random, large thumbnail; no text anywhere in the library. So let's say you have 5 files of that are of the same content, you have no idea what you're selecting if you can't read the file name!
Also, this player has very little customization. You can't change the background (rather ugly baked-in). You can't change how the local media app loads the files; it's just all giant thumbnails. A list view would be awesome.
Lastly, this is supposed to support USB 3.0. I used an Nvidia-recommneded flash drive (over 200mbps read) and it chokes trying to play back an MP4 encoded at 30mbps. Not good!
I would not recommend this as a general media player.
Just using for Kodi and Plex. It's very fast and can play UHD content with no issue.
It works great

I got the shield TV mostly to use for Amazon Prime Video, since my ATV 4th gen didn't have it.
I think it's a great product, Nvidia GeForce streaming to my PC works great (over gigabit network), and the controller is very nice/sturdy and so is the remote. Overall very satisfied with this product!
Why 3 Stars: Well I use Comcast/Xfinity, and Comcast doesn't allow this device to be activated with HBO Go and Showtime Anytime, I know this is a Comcast related issue, but I wish Nvidia/Google would push Comcast to allow Android TV devices to be authenticated on their network. I understand I could instead use HBO Now or Showtime and directly subscribe to them, but that's at extra cost (lose cable discount) and I like the fact that I get those channels on my TV and shows recorded on Tivo as well. I have contacted both Nvidia and Comcast on their FB/Twitter feeds and there are a lot of people frustrated by Comcast's action.

I had the older version for a short time before returning it and I have had the newer one since its release. It is a great android TV device and has handled almost everything I throw at it flawlessly. Not only is it quick and powerful, but NVIDIA also performed whatever blood sacrifice is required to get Amazon to approve the Prime Instant Video app for the device. I've used it to stream games from my gaming PC and to stream content from a number of sources like Google, Hulu, Amazon, Netflix, HBO Go, and PBS. It can also stream from other devices just like a Chromecast. I have only one complaint though I have to emphasize that it is a rather consistent frustration. The remote sucks.
I loved the first iteration of the remove in the original Shield TV. It was snappy and had a very convenient headphone jack that I would use when there was too much background noise or when I wanted to quietly watch something early in the morning. Sure, the rechargeable battery likely didn't last as long and after enough time would likely fail to even hold a charge. The new remote, however, did away with the headphone jack and is incredibly frustrating to use. Commands issued to the remote (with line of site to the device and only about 7-8 feet away) are often delayed, sometimes for several seconds making you question whether your action registered, and then all commands are suddenly released in a burst. To make things worse, I frequently end up pausing content when I just set the remote down somewhere. I don't know if the change in momentum is setting off the center button or if it is something else. The capacitive touch volume slider is also very awkward to use, which is only made more frustrating when combined with the delayed response to commands. This can then result in raising the volume way too high and blowing out my ears. All of this can make using the remote very annoying. While I love the size and feel of the remote, I often switch to using the awkward game controller to control the ShieldTV instead.
I like the new controller, but it again uses the weird capacitive slider for volume and it also has some very sensitive pause, back, and home buttons in the bottom center of the controller. This often causes me to press them by accident when picking up the controller by the center.
I would recommend the unit and I wish I was vindictive enough to rate it lower just to highlight the remote issues but, alas, I like the device far too much (despite the failings of its remote) to give it anything less than 4 stars.
good

I bought this to replace my Roku Ultra, so keep in mind that I'm looking at the Shield TV as an upgraded streaming box for my home theater, not a console for my gaming arsenal (although, I do happen to be a gamer). My main attraction to the Shield TV is that it's the only streaming box other than Roku Ultra that supports 4k HDR. The Shield TV turned out to be an upgrade in every aspect.
About Controls:
First of all, it works just fine with my Logitech Harmony Companion remote, which comes with a Harmony Hub. Older Harmony remotes may not work, or may have to use some kind of workaround, but the current generation Harmony remote works beautifully.
The controller is very very nice. Far beyond the quality I expected. My biggest nitpick is the omission of "Start" and "Select" buttons, which can be problematic when emulating Playstation games.
Third Party bluetooth controllers seem right at home with the Shield TV. My 8Bitdo pad paired right up and works great. Any paired remote, gamepad, keyboard, or mouse will work for all menus, so you can use pretty much whatever you want, as long as it's bluetooth or USB, and Android compatible.
Browsing through menus, Netflix, etc. is very snappy and responsive, owing to the overkill processor this thing is packing. Android compatible game emulators such as EPSXE and Mupen64 run very well, although keep in mind that retro game emulation always has minor bugs that have nothing to do with how powerful your hardware is.
Netflix runs exactly as well as it did on the Roku Ultra. I have installed a Cat6 port to avoid dealing with wifi, but before I got that done, everything worked as expected over wifi.
Youtube actually works a bit better, as viewing different resolution videos on the Roku always threw my receiver for a loop for some reason. By best guess on this is that maybe the Shield TV upscales everything to the resolution you set, rather than letting youtube change the output size, forcing receivers to autodetect every time. Whatever the reason, my Youtube experience is much improved.
The thing I like most about this platform is the freedom. Android TV is basically just Android OS, so you can sideload a lot of useful apps and just use a mouse in lieu of touch input. In other words, it's an open platform, and you can do more or less whatever you want.
It's not perfect. There will be some issues and annoyances that will be dealbreakers for some people. It's not for everybody, but speaking as a home theater enthusiast who likes games, it's an absolute slam dunk for me.
Unfortunately, since I'm running AMD graphics in my PC, I haven't been able to try streaming games from my PC, but I've had such a positive experience with the SHIELD TV so far, I'm more likely to buy an NVIDIA graphics card in the future to gain the option of PC gaming in the living room.

Would I buy it again. YES.
THAT SAYS IT ALL
Love it! 5 Stars

We bought the Nvidia Shield to replace a much beloved Amazon Fire TV. While we really liked the Fire TV (1st Gen) it seemed underpowered for the type of streaming that we were doing. While we had no interest in the gaming aspect of the Shield, and it was a good bit more expensive then a new Fire TV, it seemed like the most robust streaming device. My husband is a IT expert and puts a lot of research into these types of devices.
We had already owned the previously mentioned Fire TV, and have also owned a Fire TV Stick and three different Roku devices. As cord cutters for several years now this device is the heart of our AV system and needed to have the power to handle both live streaming as well as local media files. Kodi runs very well on it as do the other apps that we’ve installed.
Our biggest complaint would have to be the remote. While it has a nice feel, and is very stylish, it is extremely touchy. Just shifting it around in your hand can cause you to close out of an app or jump out of a program. I much prefer the remote from the Amazon Fire TV over this one. Other than that, the Shield is the best streaming option that you can find.

love it

1. Delivery
As many other customers must have earlier testified, Amazon always goes the extra mile in ensuring that their customers are happy. Something similar happened with me. I ordered this product from India and as this was my first international order from Amazon I was a bit concerned as to how and when it'll reach. I opted for the standard shipping model. products.name: ASUS RT-AC88U Wireless-AC3100 Dual Band Gigabit Router, AiProtection with Trend Micro for Complete Network Security

detail.comments:
This modem will not deliver the full 1Gb Fiber speeds on Centurylink.
After configuring it correctly for their 1Gbps Internet, it could not deliver more than 650Mbps Down, and 850Mbps Up to an Ethernet-attached computer.
The Centurylink-supplied $99 router had no trouble delivering 925Mbps Down and 950Mbps Up.
While I like Asus products, this one can't do the job for Centurylink 1Gb fiber Internet. I returned it.

Initial capability was extremely impressive. It is well powered and allowed the wireless signal to reach much farther than my old router. It has worked flawlessly from when it arrived until about 3 weeks ago. The 2.4 GHz seemed to stop working for a couple of hours. My computers use the 5.0 GHz network and my kids iPads use the 2.4 GHz, so I did not notice it until they complained. The 2.4 GHz has now completely died and I am working with their technical support via email. The good news is I can switch most of the devices over to the 5.0 GHz until we get it fixed. I will post an update after I get it fixed.

Right out of the box, next day, WiFi drops intermittently(yes, checked & updated firmware, changed channels, reset ect). As we have a NAS and stream everything from a media sever this is not acceptable. Very disappointed for dropping the most money I ever have on a router, haven't been too happy with my other Asus router, guess it's time to switch back to the tride and true Linksys I used to use for years without issue.

Used several different Routers over the years.The ASUS RT-AC88U is by far the best in performance, reliability, manufacturing quality and design.
Just upgraded my internet to 300mbps and receive in the house/backyard 320mbps plus. Great product.
appears to be doing its intended job of broadcasting a long range wireless signal to all parts of my home.
Wow -- we saw our wireless internet connection for from good to great with the installation of this wireless router. Easy to install. Love it.

Great router, bought it because of the the easy to use parental controls. I love this router, everything is easy and it just works :) I use it with Gigabit internet and even under extreme usage it just works.. Bought this this one to replace netgear ac 1750... use the netgear as access point
Super dank
High speed internet. easy to set up.
It is the best product. I am really satisfied.
I like it.

My star rating has gone up and down like a roller coaster. As we tried to prefect the settings we indirectly killed our performance. We were seeing the 5.0 drop off all the time. If you google the scenario Asus AC88U dropping 5.0mhz you will find enough reading material to keep you up for days.
After a month of rebooting it at least once a day we are now stable and bridged to another Asus RT-ACRH13 as a wired bridge.
The problems we observed are not unique to Asus. All the other manufacturers have similar issues reported. It is disturbing to buy a high end router and having to struggle configuring it....rolling back 1 version on the firmware...etc. Here are some of the changes we played with to finally become stable on 5.0. Internal transfers considering the distance are great. 500mb. It is the best we will be able to achieve wireless with all the walls using Auto channel selection, 20/40/80. Locking it in on 80 was causing drops.
Locking it on 40 will not allow the 500+mb internal transfers to go so at that speed. We shut down Beamforming and MU-MIMO. Despite having an MU-MIMO device on the other end there was no performance increase and we were still dropping 5.0. Locking in a fixed channel we were also still dropping the 5.0 so we let it auto negotiate(even when we were set to 20/40/80). I believe adding the bridge router also an Asus creates a scenario for us that many will not experience over the airways with these transmitters being relatively close.
I even went as far as to buy an LB1 little USB fan to place underneath the AC88U reading that heat build up may be causing the drops.
It made no difference. That said a cool router is a happier router so I am glad I bought it. So 5 stars now for the performance as we have it configured minus 1 star as it was a pain to get it working in our environment as we desired.

Reset the router few times, same issue. I also restore the firmware to different versions, same issue...Now the router doesn't have any signal at all. It shows 3 solid light plus one purple (not red) light. Reset button is not working anymore either.
Also the coating on top of the router is cracking and start to peeling off. It looks like I receive an unit that has all the issues ever mentioned under its review here.
Love that this router has 8 LAN ports!! I don't even need a separate switch to connect all of my devices. Wireless speed is really nice and I like the router app.
Great product and fast shipping and excellent coverage and very fast speed all features available I recommend

Blown Away!! Fast & Consistently Powerful Wireless Range (for tablet, laptop, and printers), from lower rear of house to attic front side of house!! A few extra dollars wisely invested, no headaches, no sluggishness.

works great thanks

Edit: First of all I would like to change my review of this device because the issue I was having is not the fault of the router, rather its the fault of the Ethernet cable that was being used between the cable modem and the router and the stock Asus firmware which still will not work right with Comcast cable. I'm using the supplied cable to the second ISP as I run dual WAN so I used the old cable from the modem to the router WAN port. I narrowed down the possibilities to the modem or the cable and tried switching the Ethernet cable with a high quality high bandwidth shielded cat 6 cable. Since doing that I have not lost my IPv6 connection to the modem using Merlin's firmware and all clients on my network have been able to retain their wired and wireless IPv6 connections with absolutely no downtime. I am still running Merlin's firmware version 380.66 alpha 3 which is working great for me and incorporates some of Asus's 7378 improvements that have not yet been included in the official firmware for this unit. Asus should consider some prefix designation specific settings for their IPv6 menu that mimic those that Merlin has incorporated into his menu for customers using Comcast cable.
The radio is strong and covers my house with a strong 5ghz signal that no other router I've ever owned could do. In many places even the netgear r8000 I tried last year left dead zones that the RT-AC88U covers. The interface GUI is very intuitive and offers many settings and an ease of navigation that other routers don't offer. Although this model allows for two DNS server designations I would like to see 3 or more in the menu. I have used this unit in failover mode with Comcast as my primary provider and AT&T VDSL as the second ISP and after properly configuring the AT&T modem/router to DMZ the IP address to the router it works just fine. Currently I'm using load balancing with a ratio of 8:2 and my clients are able to access the network without any issues. I also like how the network map shows the clients and their connection method along with time connected and RX/TX speeds which is something that no other router I've owned has done.
Asus you still need to revise your firmware and how it handles an IPv6 connection to Comcast cable so users can obtain an IPv6 address for their clients. I tried the stock 7266 firmware this morning and it will not obtain an IPv6 address from Comcast, however, just as soon as I reload any Merlin firmware version it will immediately obtain an IPv6 connection to Comcast using prefix designation.
Again I must apologize as it was my Ethernet cable that was the issue all along and not the router and I have adjusted my review to reflect that the error was on my end and not with this product. I have included a picture of Merlin's IPv6 menu so Asus can see what Comcast customers would like to see incorporated into the stock firmware.

This was my second ASUS Router, after the AC66U, which for the price and longevity was and still is a phenomenal router. I purchased the AC88U in hope it would increase our wifi signal throughout our apartment and provide faster device-device transfer speeds. The router performed amazingly well when it worked... We have Spectrum Ultimate 300Mbps Internet and on the 5GHz band we would pull 330-355Mbps download, but the 5GHz band dropped connection frequently and had terrible range. I sat 10 feet from router and had less than 70% signal on 5G and 85% signal on 2.4G. The 2.4G was stable and reliable but transfer speeds were expected, no more than 100Mbps. I reset the router 3 times in hopes of making the 5G network come back alive after it would go off. It worked for one week and again we would have same issue. I love ASUS routers and their user interface but this particular model is very buggy and runs extremely warm. I loved having the 8 Ethernet ports as well, but for now I'm going back to my reliable AC66U.

Turning BT off and on again does not restore it. Only a reboot does. Then again BT works great until the next connectivity loss The instructions that come with the device say it is just Plug N' Play with Windows 10. Only be sure to remove any previous BT software, of which I have none (in Device Manager only the Logitech mouse, the Pluggable device, Device Identification, and Microsoft Services show). The previous BT adapter and the Logitech mouse were both used as Plug N' Play devices with no management software or drivers others than those provided by Windows installed for either. But whatever the actually origin of the problem is, I fault Pluggable for leaving the user holding the bag. I've never had a Logitech BT device that tells me that I as a user must become a "geek" to use their device. The Logitech installations are very user-friendly and pretty much do all the work and thinking for the user. Pluggable should do the same.
Update(4/9/17). Reinstalling the driver in Device Manager on my Win10 computer also fixes lost connectivity, at least temporarily. Find the Broadcomm BCM20702 Bluetooth 4.0 USB Device under Bluetooth. Mouse right click, Pick Update Driver, then Browse My Computer, then Let Me Pick From a List of Available Drivers, then Broadcomm BCM20702 Bluetooth 4.0 USB Device. It may take one or two minutes to reinstall the driver. After that I regained connectivity without having to reboot.

products.name: eero Home WiFi System (Pack of 3) - Blanket Your Home in WiFi, Replaces Wireless Router and Range Extender, Gigabit Speed, WPA2 Encryption

detail.comments: It just works. It's as simple as that. Simple set up (supported on both Android and iOS), unobtrusive hardware and updates are pushed out as opposed to me going out to search for them. Instead of wasting time with configurations and terrible routers from Telcos (which I have usually ditched and swapped out with dd-wrt capable hardware), I no longer have to even think about this. That alone is worth the price point.

These appear to have resolved a problem of spotty wifi around my house. Set up was very easy. The only problem I had was that after getting these set up, they auto-updated the software and the app got frozen -- although the eeros themselves were working. I finally deleted the app and reinstalled it and everything has been good since then. I am surprised that I do get an occasional message when trying to use my iPad and my Apple TV, both in the same room as an eero, telling me that the signal is too weak. There is a clear line of sight between all three devices and the Apple TV is close to the eero but a bit lower. I'll experiment a bit with placement and assume this will be resolved. Regardless, I would recommend these because of the design, ease of set up and blanket coverage elsewhere in my house.
Installed in ten minutes and allowed fast wifi throughout our home and two out buildings! Worked as promised!

We live in a 3-level, 4K+ sqft house. The 3-pack has eliminated all dead spots. The interface allows me to see who is using my system and then block them if I so choose. We run mostly Apple devices and an Xbox seamlessly. I installed this last October and have seen it improve over that time from initial download speeds in the 30-40s to what we have now. Our download speeds after the last update are consistently over 100Mbps. The system does seem to "learn" your house.

The set I received was very easy to setup, and it worked great... for the first day. The next day I woke to find one of the units had overheated so I returned the set. I read online that everyone says they are very warm when on so I decided not to risk future failures and have decided to try the Linksys Velop system. Maybe when eero comes out with version 2 they will put in a better heatsink. I think they concentrated too much on aesthetics and not enough on functionality.

This system does all it says it will. My download speed is considerably better throughout our condo. We now have no dead zones, and moving between rooms doesn't cause connection problems. It is easy to set up, and configure, and so far I have gotten 2 software updates, something I never got with Linksys.
Easy to install and works extremely well. Replaced all previous wifi routers.

Finally, no dead spots in my house! I've tried many products to cover my 5000 sp ft two story home, but there were always dead spots. Not any more. after spending about 30 minutes experimenting with locations for my FOUR Eero's, I finally have whole house coverage without any dead spots. It was very easy to set up and requires zero maintenance or updating so far (3 months). It was worth spending nearly $000 to have zero Wifi headaches.

This is the best router on the market. My husband found the router and once again he has out done himself. The reception and signal strength the Eero gives is better then any router we have had before. We have an older two story home 2400 sq ft. Never a problem anymore, my husband has full strength out in his shop that's about 200 ft from the house. Now that is a first. All this is being done with just two Eeros right now. Anyone that calls these routers garbage doesn't know what they are talking about.
Easy to use and app is voice accessibility
Best purchase ever!!! No more connection issues. I live in an apartment complex its clean and I get to laugh at my neighbors who continue to buy extenders for their 2 bedroom units. Lol

This is the most amazing wifi product that I have ever owned. To my amazement I installed it in minutes and it has been working flawlessly for many months now. I no longer have any dead spots in my home or even around my home. I plan on adding 2 more nodes in the future, one for my garage and possibly another at the pool.
The system is expensive but i have found that it is worth every penny i paid for it. No more wifi complaints!!!!!

This has made wi-fi almost as fast and easy as wired service. For the first time, I have very fast and uniform wi-fi service in our large old house. The system was easy to install. When I did have a glitch, I was able to get eero tech support on the phone quickly and talk to a very helpful real human being. He guided me through resolution in just a few minutes. This is a great device from a customer-friendly business.

Installed eeros in both our apartment and a vacation home. Both have multiple levels. In general only one is needed on each floor. The system works perfectly in both locations. Streaming is flawless. I had a problem with the installation of one of the units. Called customer service and a lovely woman walked me thru a fix. She stayed on the phone with me until we were sure it was working.

I've had this for about 6 months now. Works great. Great coverage across my house and yard, and stable as a rock.
I had a problem early on where some devices would just momentarily disconnect from the wifi and then reconnect (and page loads and stuff would time-out in between). It was annoying, and started getting more frequent. I contacted support, and they were very responsive. They reported back that one of the units was reporting that it was overheating indicating that it might be defective, so they sent me a replacement unit for it. That resolved my problem.
Its a good product and service has been good, and overall I am satisfied with it, but its still pretty dang expensive for what it is (hence the 4 stars).

This system has been an incredible addition to my home. After installation my sunroom went from 1.15mb to 64.56mb and my outdoor patio went from 5.7mb to 42.12. Unreal coverage throughout the home and incredibly easy set up! Everyone needs to own one of these.

If you are looking to create a home network and get coverage throughout your whole house this is the tool for you. They are literally the size of a small piece of sandwich bread that is overstuffed with fillings. We have had great coverage and increased the ability our internet to handle more devices. Yes we have the almighty (crappy) Spectrum formally time warner cable.
Great product. Exceeded expectations.

Love our eeros! We bought the three pack for our 4 bedroom house - we have 1 in the living room, 1 in the back office (where we could never get a good internet connection before), and 1 in the basement. Incredibly easy to set up - the packaging is beautiful, the eeros are pretty sleek looking, and the instructions are thorough and straightforward. We had the eeros for about 3 months now - no issues.Would highly recommend.

Simply amazing. Easy to set up. I did need to hard wire my first two eeros to each other. Going from the main eero downstairs to the others upstairs rendered a weak signal, but hard wiring it was worth it. I'm getting over 200mb in my past deads spots, such as the master bed room and deck, which makes this purchase worth the money as it works and communicates with itself to keep working and it did not interfere with my TV downstairs I have hard wired to the xfinity modem. I read of Issues with LUMA having issues with existing hardwired connecitons.
Best tech purchase ever! So easy to use and the tech support was amazing when things were a bit slow after a network update!
I have had zero issues with the wifi in my 3 story home since installing eero. I couldn't be happier. It took a matter of minutes to set up, and I am not exactly a tech savvy girl.

I bought these to replace a couple of Ethernet connected Apple AirPorts which have been getting progressively worse in terms of throughput and stability. They're 3+ years old, which is far beyond the lifespan of most WiFi routers that I've had in the past.
I have a decent sized home, so I knew that a normal WiFi router wasn't going to fit the bill. I narrowed the choices down to the eero, Google WiFi, and the Netgear Orbi. I've been watching the eero's for well over a year now, and based on other stellar reviews, I decided to take the leap and buy them.
The eero "kit" comes with three units that are fairly small--about 4 inches square and an inch high. They come in a handsome box and are packaged much like your typical Apple device. Very easy to open and very little instructions are provided (or needed). Simply unbox them, install the smartphone app (iOS and Android supported), and plug the first one (marked 'Start Here') to your internet modem and power. Then fire up the smart phone app, which leads you through the process of naming and configuring the eero. Took literally about 3 minutes.
After the first eero is up and running, you repeat the process for the other two, sans the connect-to-Internet-modem part. They recommend the second unit is placed somewhere around the middle of the house, and the third unit at the far end of the house. The two "satellite" units do not require any connectivity other than power. Setup was even easier with the app--literally 60 seconds or so.
And since I kept the same network name (SSID) and WPA2 password that I used with my old AirPorts, all of my wireless devices magically connected to the eeros with no reconfiguration required. The eero app allows you to quickly see which devices are connected, which eero they're connected to, and their signal strength.
Now for the cool part. WiFi throughput is unbelievable. On newer devices that support 802.11a, I'm routinely getting 100 mbps throughput. Older devices are also pretty darn fast, in the 40-50 mbps range. Another great feature of the eero is that the three units all work together as a single unit, so you can roam around the house and can be pretty much guaranteed "5 bar" signal strength everywhere, with no drop outs. Fantastic!
I did wind up connecting my furthest eero to an Ethernet "hard line" as I already had a line down there, and I get slightly better throughput that way. That said, if I didn't have the line already down there, I would have been perfectly happy running both satellites in wireless mode. The throughput of the units continues to impress me, especially with the entire household on them--18 devices on average. I have noticed an appreciable increase in the performance of streaming apps and devices like NetFlix, Plex, Roku and Chromecasts.
Another great feature is the ability to assign WiFi devices to profiles, which can then be assigned to a schedule. This is great for kids, as it's possible to automatically (or manually) "pause" their Internet access, such as during dinner time or at night. And the smartphone app makes it really easy to manually pause access. It takes literally 15 seconds to pause/unpause internet access.
In summary, I'm happy as a clam with my eeros. Although they required a significant investment, I couldn't be happier with the ease of setup and performance delivered. If you've got the money and your WiFi coverage is driving you nuts, don't hesitate to run out and get a set of these gems. You'll be glad you did!

Easy setup

Better coverage 100% of my property instead of 75% of my house. Covers roughly 8,000 sq/ft.

After an amazingly simple and Apple-like setup, my wifi issues were solved. No more dropoffs and inconsistent speed. I was finally getting the wifi I was paying for. I'm using a 2 device system in a 1300 square foot home.

Due to the fact I had an Arris router/modem combo for Xfinity I had to switch the router to Bridge modem to account for the new Eero introduced to the network. Setup was simple. Even better, if you name the Eero wireless network the same as your previous network, with the same password, all your devices automatically connect without the need to re-login.
Even more impressive is the customer service. I wanted to make sure my setup was ideal. I figured if I were going to invest in this type of system, I want it done perfectly. I decided to create a layout of my home with Visio to send to the Eero team. They assured me after reviewing my layout that my setup was perfect. I asked if another Eero would have been necessary and they suggested my setup was perfect. No oversell. Just quality customer service and timely feedback.
I have not experienced one hiccup since using Eero. Access points are always up and my speeds are always optimal. I have Xfinity with 50MB down and 12MB up. I consistently hold speeds around 88 down and 12 up in every last square inch of my house, including bathrooms with doors closed.
One last thing. Eero has improved the range so well on my Wifi that my Arlo cameras hold full signal outside of the house. I also have an AT&T Microcell to boost my signal. I can now hookup to the Microcell as I pull into the driveway.
I’d like to add one more Eero to my master bedroom to create even better handoff from Office -> Room -> Downstairs but not ready to invest yet.
I love this product. You will not be disappointed.
super simple to set up. Eero just works and works well.

products.name: ARRIS SURFboard SB6141 DOCSIS 3.0 Cable Modem - Retail Packaging - White

detail.comments: A product that you spend so much on that is supposed to be a step above the rest should be a step above the rest. This is far from it. It has a great WiFi signal when you are in eyesight of it. If you are not within eyesight of it, you can forget connecting via WiFi.
Motorola has always made the best modems. No problems with it at all in the past 2 years unlike the cheap junk modems Comcast will give you.

Bought this 6 months ago, now apparently my modem keeps restarting itself. Not sure why buy the warranty was only valid for a month. Now I have to go buy a new modem. I'll probably end up buying from cox store, the warranty is good for 2 years and they'll break the payments up. Don't waste your money like I did.
Works great
Works as designed

This was pretty easy to set up, but I think we got a lemon. Internet at our house was intermittent at best when we used this machine. I had to restart it more than 5 times a day. In the month we used it, we ended up using lots of extra cell phone data because our home wireless was so frustrating.
excellent

I bought this to replace my old Ubee wifi router/modem that I was leasing through TWC (now Spectrum). Installation was easy, directions are straight forward, and I was up and running after a few minutes and calling the cable company. Immediately I noticed better performance (in terms of speed) than with the old router/modem.
The problem lies in the overall range of the router/modem (talking about the 6700, specifically). I live in a 1500 sq ft ranch with the modem setup in the living room. Even at the other end of the house, where our bedroom is (again, it's only a ranch, so it's not that long), the signal was starting to weaken. My laptop also shows 4 out of 5 bars of signal strength sitting on the couch 10 feet away. Also, the signal has trouble reaching my PS4 in the room directly below where the router/modem is. I also have to regularly reset the router/modem to connect to my PS4 because it won't pick up the signal. I'm not sure if this is due to a weak signal strength or an issue with the PS4; however, I will say, with the Ubee model from TWC (which I consider to be inferior) I never once had a problem picking up the signal in other rooms of the house.
Final thoughts: good performance and speeds; not so good on the signal strength.
Great product, would buy again
Works great. Easy to install.
Kept showing as 'out of range', unable to connect regularly. I wouldn't buy this brand again.
Modem works perfect!
Reliable high speed modem - may not be the most up-to-date - but it provides the necessary speeds for most households. Solid 80-90mbps connection can be expected.

Easy to set up and customize settings. However it did not like working with my Kaspersky antivirus software. It took a lot of time plus a couple of contacts with ARRIS to figure this out. I was starting to get annoyed with Kaspersky anyway so I removed it from my system. With Kaspersky no longer on my system I have had great results. I do have to give just the four stars because I would expect any modem to work with most popular security software. Since Kaspersky was an issue there may be more software that creates problems as well.
Much better then the cheap outdated cable modem / router my ISP was charging me 9.99 a month. Easy setup and far better performance.

I've only had this WiFi router a couple days and it seems to be working very well, my wifi signal is a lot stronger than the previous wifi router I had.
This router was very easy to setup and the instructions were very easy to understand. If your looking for a WiFi router that will get the job done I very much would recommend this WiFi Router. This WiFi router has ridiculously long range it's awesome!
I plan on updating this review overtime.
